ANTHONY J. PERAICA, MIKE QUIGLEY, PETER N. SILVESTRI, DEBORAH SIMS
and LARRY SUFFREDIN, County Commissioners
PROPOSED RESOLUTION

WHEREAS, the members of the Cook County Board of Commissioners are proud to recognize
excellence in community and team sports; and
WHEREAS, the Cook County Board of Commissioners recognizes the importance of community team
sports in developing the qualities of team work, respect, hard work and dedication in children; and
WHEREAS, the Lemont Little League All Star team displayed those qualities and worked together with
their coaches, Michael Hall, Dave Rimkus and Bob Soria, to achieve a great season and progress to the
second round of the Little League World Series; and
WHEREAS, Lemont became the first Illinois team to qualify for the Little League World Series in I 4
years and the first Southwest Suburban Cook County team to qualify since the league was created; and
WHEREAS, Lemont progressed through the double elimination round of the World Series with a record
in Illinois of I I wins and no losses; and
WHEREAS, teammates Austin Mastela, Michael Hall, Andrew Hoffmeister, Marty Joyce, Michael
Kamp, Dane Kempke, Zak Kutsulis, David Rimkus, Zack Soria , Chris Stoeberl, Jeffery Worsech, David
Hearne and Josh Ferry and coaches Michael Hall, Dave Rimkus and Bob Soria are to be congratulated on
leading Lemont Little League to a great post season we are all proud of.
NOW, THEREFORE, BE IT RESOLVED, that the members of the Cook County Board of
Commissioners join their family and friends in congratulating the coaching staff and team members of the
Lemont Little League Team on their great achievements and their sense of teamwork, respect, hard work
and dedication; and
BE IT FURTHER RESOLVED, that this Resolution be spread across the official text of the
proceedings of this Honorable Body and that suitable copies hereof be presented to the coaching staff and
team members.

This item was WITHDRAWN at the request of the sponsor.

34

 JOURNAL OF PROCEEDINGS FOR SEPTEMBER 7, 2006

* * * * *
Submitting a Proposed Resolution sponsored by
JOSEPH MARIO MORENO, County Commissioner
Co-Sponsored by
ANTHONY J. PERAICA, DEBORAH SIMS, ELIZABETH ANN DOODY GORMAN,
JOAN PATRICIA MURPHY and PETER N. SILVESTRI, County Commissioners
PROPOSED RESOLUTION
WHEREAS, Cook County government is currently facing a serious budget crisis, with a projected
shortfall approaching $56 million and the FY2007 budget process looming on the horizon; and
WHEREAS, Cook County government is making concerted efforts to reduce the budgetary deficit by
eliminating duplicity in various government functions through consolidation, increasing revenue
collection efforts, and improving efficiencies through technological upgrades, among other measures; and
WHEREAS, the many departments that make up the government of Cook County are or may need to cut
jobs; and
WHEREAS, further undesirable cuts in jobs and core services may also result from an unresolved budget
deficit; and
WHEREAS, in the interest of Cook County Government, the employees of the government and the
citizens of the County, it is the desire of this government to consider all ideas to help resolve this crisis
and balance the budget, which is required by state law; and
WHEREAS, it has been consistently shown that empowering all employees of an organization, be it in
the private or public sector, to participate in employee suggestion programs has yielded tangible results
through generation of ideas for cost saving measures, improved efficiency, process improvements,
identification of new revenue streams and elimination of wasteful spending; and
WHEREAS, meritorious ideas know no boundaries and can be produced by any level of employee in an
organization; and
WHEREAS, active engagement by employees gives an organization a competitive advantage and is
instrumental to its success.
NOW, THEREFORE, BE IT RESOLVED, that the Cook County Board of Commissioners does
hereby request the formation of an employee suggestion program enabling all Cook County employees to
participate in generating and submitting ideas with the explicit goal of reducing expenditures, improving
efficiencies and effectiveness, increasing revenue, and eliminating wasteful spending in an effort to close
the budget shortfall for FY2006 and present and ratify a balanced budget for FY2007.

Commissioner Moreno, seconded by Commissioner Silvestri, moved to suspend the rules so that this
matter may be considered. The motion carried unanimously.
Commissioner Moreno, seconded by Commissioner Silvestri, moved that the Proposed Resolution be
referred to the Committee on Finance. (Comm. No. 281395). The motion carried unanimously.

35

 JOURNAL OF PROCEEDINGS FOR SEPTEMBER 7, 2006

* * * * *
Submitting a Proposed Resolution sponsored by
JOSEPH MARIO MORENO, County Commissioner
PROPOSED RESOLUTION

WHEREAS, Cook County government is charged with presenting a balanced budget each fiscal year, as
mandated by the Illinois Constitution; and
WHEREAS, the budget process and the budget itself should be transparent so as to allow for proper
scrutiny by the public, whose tax dollars help fund it; and
WHEREAS, a transparent budget allows the Cook County Board of Commissioners to also properly
scrutinize and adjust it if necessary, through the amendment process, to help identify and eliminate
wasteful spending, as well as improve efficiencies; and
WHEREAS, Cook County government has an approximately $3 billion budget and allocates portions of
it to fund independent organizations, either directly or through one of its various departments; and
WHEREAS, currently these allocations appear simply as a line item in the annual appropriation bill or
not at all if funded by a governmental department; and
WHEREAS, it is this government' s obligation to ensure that monies are spent judiciously by funding
programs that have the highest return on investment via cost savings to the County and benefits to its
citizens; and
WHEREAS, it is difficult, if not impossible, to properly analyze the value of the return on investment of
these various organizations from a line item budget entry; and
WHEREAS, in order to determine which programs are effective and financially sound and worthy of
continued funding, it is necessary to have a tool documenting its effectiveness and cost savings.
NOW, THEREFORE, BE IT RESOLVED, that the Cook County Board of Commissioners, does
hereby request that any organization funded wholly or in part by the government of Cook County directly
or via one of its departments present an annual financial and impact report to this Honorable Body, so as
to properly document the associated cost savings, economic impact and effectiveness of the County
funded programs provided by these organizations.
This item was WITHDRAWN at the request of the sponsor.

* * * * *
Submitting a Proposed Resolution sponsored by
JOSEPH MARIO MORENO, County Commissioner
Co-Sponsored by
DEBORAH SIMS, ELIZABETH ANN DOODY GORMAN, JOAN PATRICIA MURPHY
and PETER N. SILVESTRI, County Commissioners
PROPOSED RESOLUTION

WHEREAS, each year, Cook County government is tasked with the difficult job of presenting a balanced
budget, while still providing the essential services, upon which its citizens depend; and

36

 JOURNAL OF PROCEEDINGS FOR SEPTEMBER 7, 2006

WHEREAS, Cook County government is making concentrated efforts to find ways to reduce
expenditures, improve efficiencies, eliminate wasteful spending, and increase revenues, not just for this
year, but for future years; and
WHEREAS, it is the responsibility of all departments that make up the government of Cook County to
proactively search for ways in which to accomplish these necessary financial goals; and
WHEREAS, undesirable cuts in core services may result from continued budgetary problems now and in
the future; and
WHEREAS, it is our fiduciary responsibility as elected officials, to constantly look for new and
innovative ways to save taxpayers' money, while still providing "best in class" services, for which Cook
County has become known; and
WHEREAS, it has been shown that in the domain of Information Technology that reliance on
mainframes is increasingly a costly and less flexible option for governments; and
WHEREAS, in light of this reality, more and more governments have looked and opted for new, more
efficient and less costly computer platforms to run their programs; and
WHEREAS, as a result, only 4 counties in Illinois other than Cook County currently use mainframe
computer platforms, and only about 88 in the entire nation; and
WHEREAS, reduced reliance on a mainframe, by migrating to an alternative IBM computer platform
that will run Legacy Cobol applications, would eliminate the need for costly upgrades and continued
leasing of the County's current mainframe; and
WHEREAS, using FY2005 data, the current three year lease for the County mainframe is $11.7 million
and migrating to an IBM alternative platfonn, such as iSeries or pSeries, would have a one-time cost of
approximately $1.5 million; and
WHEREAS, if implemented before the end of FY2007, a potential cost savings of at least $15 million
could be realized by the end of FY2010.
NOW, THEREFORE, BE IT RESOLVED, that the Cook County Board of Commissioners, does
hereby request an analysis of the current County IBM mainframe to compare it with alternative IBM
platfonns that exist on the market today for the express purpose of determining whether or not we are
taking advantage of the best technology available at the least cost to Cook County.

Commissioner Moreno, seconded by Commissioner Silvestri, moved to suspend the rules so that this
matter may be considered. The motion carried unanimously.
Commissioner Moreno, seconded by Commissioner Silvestri, moved that the Proposed Resolution be
referred to the Committee on Finance. (Comm. No. 281396). The motion carried unanimously.

37

 JOURNAL OF PROCEEDINGS FOR SEPTEMBER 7, 2006

* * * * *
Submitting a Proposed Resolution sponsored by
JOSEPH MARIO MORENO, County Commissioner
Co-Sponsored by
JERRY BUTLER, ELIZABETH ANN DOODY GORMAN and JOAN PATRICIA MURPHY,
County Commissioners
PROPOSED RESOLUTION
WHEREAS, Cook County government is assigned the challenging job of managing the County's public
health services, which is the second largest public health system in the nation; and
WHEREAS, this system serves as a safety net for our residents who are unable to afford private
healthcare; and
WHEREAS, it is the responsibility of the government of Cook County to ensure that companies
contracting with the County's Bureau of Health Services honor the tenns of their contracts both for the
duration of the initial contract and for any extensions that may have been granted; and
WHEREAS, if there is the possibility that the tenns of a contract, such as price or services, and/or
subsequent extensions to said contract have not been honored, it is incumbent upon this Honorable Body
to conduct an audit to verify that no irregularities have occurred; and
WHEREAS, McKesson Phannaceutical received numerous extensions, starting at the end of the original
contract on June 30, 2005 through July 31, 2006, costing taxpayers millions of dollars for each extension,
which has raised questions as to whether the terms of the original contract, for example but not limited to,
actual amount spent compared to prices quoted and one day turnarounds for emergency ordering without
backordering, were being honored during these extensions; and
WHEREAS, an audit is necessary to assure that taxpayers' money is safeguarded and was not being used
improperly and that this government is doing everything in its power to deliver quality service in the most
efficient and cost effective manner possible, without the specter of impropriety.
NOW, THEREFORE, BE IT RESOLVED, that the Cook County Board of Commissioners, does
hereby request a full audit be conducted of McKesson Pharmaceutical for the three year period of the
original contract, as well as all extensions to said contract to detennine if the conditions of the original
contract were adhered to for the entire duration of their relationship with the County of Cook.

Commissioner Moreno, seconded by Commissioner Silvestri, moved to suspend the rules so that this
matter may be considered. The motion carried unanimously.
Commissioner Moreno, seconded by Commissioner Silvestri, moved that the Proposed Resolution be
referred to the Committee on Finance. (Comm. No. 28 I 397). The motion carried unanimously.

38

 JOURNAL OF PROCEEDINGS FOR SEPTEMBER 7, 2006

* * * * *
Submitting a Proposed Resolution sponsored by
JOSEPH MARIO MORENO, County Commissioner
PROPOSED RESOLUTION

WHEREAS, Cook County government is currently working diligently to shore up the current shortfall in
the FY2006 budget; and
WHEREAS, the FY2007 budget already faces an estimated $300 million dollar deficit that must be
resolved in order to present a balanced budget as mandated by state law; and
WHEREAS, it is the duty of this Honorable Body to find and implement any possible revenue source
that can be exploited to ameliorate the County ' s financial situation; and
WHEREAS, Medicare has a number of claims, which are paid incorrectly, as much as 2%, most of
which are underpayments; and
WHEREAS, because these errors occur infrequently the majority of hospitals are unaware of them; and
WHEREAS, these errors can result from incorrect billing by the hospital, as well as incorrect payments
by the intennediary; and
WHEREAS, due to the complexity of Medicare's Outpatient Claims Review, CMS (Centers for
Medicare & Medicaid Services) is also prone to errors, some of which go undetected; and
WHEREAS, all of these claims can be resubmitted to obtain the correct payment; and
WHEREAS, an opportunity exists to audit previously paid Medical Part A claims to recover monies for
the County that were mistakenly remitted by the Fiscal Intennediary; and
WHEREAS, this opportunity is time sensitive due to Medicare' s timely filing deadline of December 31,
2006;and
WHEREAS, because of these filing deadlines, it is imperative that this Board acts expeditiously to
ensure that these monies are recovered; and
WHEREAS, the Cook County Bureau of Health Services may lack the expertise and resources to
undertake such an endeavor; and
WHEREAS, Nebo Systems, Inc., currently under contract with Cook County to provide Retroactive
Claims Reprocessing, has successfully partnered with Vaughn Holland Consulting on similar projects and
are experts in this field .
NOW, THEREFORE, BE IT RESOLVED, that the Cook County Board of Commissioners, does
hereby request Nebo Systems, Inc. be awarded a temporary sole source contract until December 31, 2006
for the recovery of monies from incorrectly paid Medicare claims; and
BE IT FURTHER RESOLVED, that this process be accomplished promptly, so as not to miss the filing
deadlines and consequently lose this revenue opportunity.
This item was WITHDRAWN at the request of the sponsor.

39

 JOURNAL OF PROCEEDTNGS FOR SEPTEMBER 7, 2006

* * * * *
Submitting a Proposed Resolution sponsored by
EARLEAN COLLTNS, County Commissioner
PROPOSED RESOLUTION
REVOLVING LOAN FUND RESOLUTION
WHEREAS, after the events of September 11, 200 I there have been additional public safety and
sanitation requirements placed on small municipalities and other local units of government; and
WHEREAS, small municipalities and other local units of government have suffered hardships in meeting
these obligations due to cash flow problems; and
WHEREAS, these problems have a negative affect on the economy of small municipalities and other
local units of government as well as the County; and
WHEREAS, small municipalities and other units of local government rely heavily on property taxes for
public safety; this has placed them at a financial disadvantage in meeting their obligations; and
WHEREAS, the cost of providing services are on the increase due to labor cost and employee benefits;
and
WHEREAS, there is a definite need to alleviate the financial burden being experienced by municipalities
and local units of government.
NOW, THEREFORE, BE IT RESOLVED, that the President of the Cook County Board of
Commissioners commission a study to examine the feasibility of establishing a revolving loan fund to aid
financially distressed municipalities and local units of government. The committee shall report its
findings and recommendations to the President not later than June 1, 2003.

Commissioner Moreno, seconded by Commissioner Silvestri, moved to suspend the rules so that this
matter may be considered. The motion carried unanimously.
Commissioner Collins, seconded by Commissioner Murphy, moved that the Proposed Resolution be
referred to the Committee on Finance. (Comm. No. 281399). The motion carried unanimously.

* * * * *
Submitting a Proposed Resolution sponsored by
PETER N. SILVESTRI and LARRY SUFFREDTN, County Commissioners
PROPOSED RESOLUTION
COUNTY GOVERNMENT RELATIONS POLICY
WHEREAS, the effectiveness of a government relations effort will reflect, m large measure, the
importance and priority ascribed to it by the chief executive; and

40

 JOURNAL OF PROCEEDfNGS FOR SEPTEMBER 7, 2006

WHEREAS, department heads should understand that requests for bill impact analyses and positions
should be answered promptly and be considered a priority; and
WHEREAS, prompt decision making is vital; thus the ultimate decision-maker on government relations
should consider it a priority to make all necessary decisions well before any applicable legislative
deadline; and
WHEREA~, the County Board may include as a resource the assistance of Commissioners with prior
experience in state government and Commissioners should be regularly informed of County interests,
and, where help is needed, encouraged to assist in the effort; and

WHEREAS, within the bounds of propriety, requests from legislators should be responded to promptly;
and
WHEREAS, government relations efforts pursued by independently elected County officials will be
required to seek County Board approval of government relations efforts and on specific legislative
initiatives; and
WHEREAS, legislative leaders will give representatives of the County a degree of responsiveness that
reflects their respective ability to: (I) generally speak for, or promptly get authority on specific topics to
speak for, the chief executive; and (II) respond to proper requests from legislators.
NOW, THEREFORE, BE IT RESOLVED, that the County's legislative agenda (I) should be finalized
before January I st (II) in the final quarter of the year, department heads and independently elected
executive offices should be asked for recommendations on legislative initiatives; (III) initial meetings
between the President and legislative leaders, and the President and the Governor, should occur prior to
the first day of regular session; (JV) fact sheets should be finalized and sponsors lined up well before bill
introduction deadlines; (V) supporters of the County's legislative agenda should be briefed prior to bill
introduction; and (VI) board ratification of a proactive agenda should occur prior to bill introduction; and
BE IT FURTHER RESOLVED, that the County develop a set of general guidelines for the government
relations team to follow, including opposition to pre-emption of home rule authority, unless the County
Board otherwise directs; and
BE IT FURTHER RESOLVED, in responding to bills and amendments that affect the County, a clear
protocol be established by the County Board, and with consistent promptness followed, establishing the
responsive roles of the Office of the President, Committee on Legislation and Intergovernmental
Relations, and the County Board on communications with the legislative leaders, state representatives and
senators and the Governor; and
BE IT FURTHER RESOLVED, that the County establish "floor leaders" in each legi slative chamber to
serve as regular spokespersons on County issues and that regular written communication to the County
Board be established by the Office of the President and the Chainnan and Vice Chainnan of the
Committee on Legislation and Intergovernmental Relations.
Commissioner Moreno, seconded by Commissioner Silvestri, moved to suspend the rules so that this
matter may be considered. The motion carried unanimously.
Commissioner Silvestri, seconded by Commissioner Suffredin, moved that the Proposed Resolution be
referred to the Committee on Legislation and Intergovernmental Relations. (Comm. No. 281403). The
motion carried unanimously.

41

 JOURNAL OF PROCEEDINGS FOR SEPTEMBER 7, 2006

* * * * *
Submitting a Proposed Resolution sponsored by
ANTHONY J. PERAICA, County Commissioner
PROPOSED RESOLUTION
RESOLUTION CALLING FOR THE APPOINTMENT OF A FEDERAL MONITOR
TO OVERSEE COOK COUNTY HIRING PRACTICES
WHEREAS, the Shakman consent decree was approved by the United States District Court in 1994; and
WHEREAS, this federal court order forbids the City of Chicago, the County of Cook, and other local
governments from hiring or firing individuals for non-exempt positions based on political considerations;
and
WHEREAS, in recent months it has become abundantly clear that the County of Cook has failed to
comply with the Shakman consent decree; and
WHEREAS, during a supposed " hiring freeze", the County of Cook hired 1300 new employees during a
six-month period; and
WHEREAS, there have been revelations of politically connected persons receiving high paying County
jobs and having test scores altered so they can receive these jobs; and
WHEREAS, the mission of Cook County Government should be honest and efficient provision of
service to the public.
NOW, THEREFORE, BE IT RESOLVED, that the President and Board of Commissioners of Cook
County, Illinois do hereby call for the appointment of a federal monitor to oversee the hiring of Cook
County employees, in order to provide more transparent government and ensure compliance with the
Shakman consent decree; and
BE IT FURTHER RESOLVED, that the President and Board of Commissioners do hereby urge the
Cook County State's Attorney's Office not to oppose the appointment and retention of a federal monitor
to oversee county hiring practices.

Commissioner Moreno, seconded by Commissioner Silvestri, moved to suspend the rules so that this
matter may be considered. The motion carried unanimously.
Commissioner Peraica, seconded by Commissioner Daley, moved that the Proposed Resolution be
referred to the Committee on Finance. (Comm. No. 281404). The motion carried unanimously.

* * * * *
Submitting a Proposed Resolution sponsored by
ROBERTO MALDONADO, County Commissioner
PROPOSED RESOLUTION
WHEREAS, the County of Cook is a home rule unit of local government pursuant to Article VII, Section
6(a) of the 1970 Illinois Constitution; and

42

 JOURNAL OF PROCEEDINGS FOR SEPTEMBER 7, 2006

WHEREAS, pursuant to its home rule power, the County of Cook may exercise any power and perfonn
any function relating to its government and affairs including the power to regulate for the protection of
the public health, safety, morals, and welfare; and
WHEREAS, to this end, the County of Cook is dedicated to providing all of its residents with equal
access to the services, opportunities, and protection county government has been established to
administer; and
WHEREAS, there are now approximately 12 million undocumented immigrants in the United States,
including half a million in Illinois and more than 300,000 in Cook County, who have been systematically
denied the opportunity enjoyed by past generations of immigrants to become legal permanent residents or
citizens of this country; and
WHEREAS, prior to 1918, the tenn " illegal immigrant" had no meaning since the United States did not
even require passports and the Mexican-U.S. border was unguarded and passed freely; and
WHEREAS, when Congress passed the National Origins Act in 1924, it began its restrictive immigration
policy, placing strict quotas on the numbers of Italians, Irish, Gennans, Jews, Japanese, and other
ethnicities, who were considered inferior by many white Protestant Americans; and
WHEREAS, in 1965, Congress repealed the National Origins Act and established a new system of
immigration restricting the number of new arrivals, but making it illegal to discriminate against applicants
because of their birthplace, race or ethnicity; and
WHEREAS, over the past two decades, immigration policy has become even more restncttve and
punitive and closed off avenues previously available for immigrants to obtain legal permanent residency,
while the U.S.-Mexico border has been further militarized; and
WHEREAS, current U.S. immigration policy does not reflect our democratic values of what is just,
humane and moral and as the current debate on comprehensive immigration reform comes to a halt, the
urgency to find real, workable solutions to modernize our archaic immigration laws becomes desperately
apparent; and
WHEREAS, the migration experience has adverse emotional and psychological effects on families,
especially those who have U.S. citizen families, including children and/or spouses, and are forced to
separate for many years due to unjust immigration policies and backlogs in visa applications; and
WHEREAS, raids carried out by the federal government, ranging from the highly publicized nationwide
workplace raids on April 17, 2006 that resulted in the arrest of I, 187 employees to the less widely known
sweeps of homes, have instilled fear and panic in immigrant communities, encouraged intimidation,
harassment and racial profiling, and led to the separation of many from their U.S. citizen families ; and
WHEREAS, one of these families recently gained national attention, when an undocumented mother,
Elvira Arellano, defied a deportation order from the U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement and
sought sanctuary in the Adalberto United Methodist Church in Chicago with her U.S. citizen son; and
WHEREAS, although the plight of Elvira and her son is the plight of millions of undocumented
immigrants with U.S. citizen families , her fate is a test case that will either set our nation on the
progressive path of real , humane, immigration reform or the regressive path of fear, repression and
intimidation; and

43

 JOURNAL OF PROCEEDINGS FOR SEPTEMBER 7, 2006
WHEREAS, according to a recent study on undocumented immigrants conducted by the University of
Illinois at Chicago's Center for Urban Economic Development, undocumented workers contribute much
more to the U.S. economy than they receive: the majority work full-time; 70% pay taxes; the majority
don' t collect tax refunds they have earned; 220,000 currently employed in Chicago contribute $5.35
billion annually to the area economy as a result of their local consumer spending; and they make far less
use of available social services than any other group; and
WHEREAS, Douglas S. Massey, a Princeton University professor and author of " Beyond Smoke and
Mirrors: Mexican Immigration in an Era of Economic Integration," further supports these statistics,
stating that in 2004 alone, undocumented workers contributed $7 billion to Social Security and $1.5
billion to Medicare with the knowledge that they would have no claim to future collection; and
WHEREAS, despite these statistics, there is a growing sentiment of hatred and intimidation of
undocumented immigrants, feelings reminiscent of nearly every historical wave of migration into the U.S.
40% of the first massive wave of immigrants that came to America between I 8 I 5 and I 860 were escaping
starvation in Ireland, but were derided as stupid, lazy and dirty, despite the fact they cleaned houses and
cared for the children of the rich and toiled in dangerous mines and filthy sweatshops; and
WHEREAS, Cook County is a leader in the movement for the protection of civil rights for
undocumented immigrants and the Cook County Board has officially urged Congress to pass fair and
humane laws that will reform our broken immigration system.
NOW, THEREFORE, BE IT RESOLVED, that the County of Cook be declared "A Sanctuary
County," a county that defends the basic human rights and dignity of undocumented immigrants and our
democratic principles of life, liberty, and justice, and all those who, as Emma Lazarus wrote in her
famous sonnet that now is engraved on a plaque at the Statue of Liberty, are "tired ... poor ... [and] ... yearn
to breathe free . .. " and recognizes that much of the historical and moral tradition of our nation is rooted in
the provision of sanctuary to those seeking a safe haven from oppression; and
BE IT FURTHER RESOLVED, that the County of Cook supports the humanitarian efforts of Reverend
Walter Coleman, who, in good faith, has opened the doors of the Adalberto United Methodist Church in
Cook County to provide sanctuary to Elvira Arellano and her U.S. citizen son and who are prepared to
accept the penalty for this act of civil disobedience in the hope that this violation of current immigration
law will lead to comprehensive immigration refonn that respects the rights of immigrants as families,
workers, and human beings; and
BE IT FURTHER RESOLVED, that the County of Cook stands in solidarity with local governments
across the nation who have declared themselves "Sanctuaries" upholding the basic human rights of
immigrants, including the cities of San Francisco, Maywood, Huntington Park and Coachella in
California and the City of Cambridge in Massachusetts; and
BE IT FURTHER RESOLVED, that the County of Cook joins several major cities, including Chicago,
Los Angeles, San Francisco, Seattle, Minneapolis, Saint Paul, and others who have official policies
prohibiting their municipal agencies from inquiring about immigration status and unilaterally enforcing
immigration law provisions, and hereby requires that no Cook County employee or department, to the
extent legally possible, will request information about or otherwise assist in the investigation of the
citizenship status of any County resident, will disseminate information regarding the citizenship of a
County resident, or condition the provision of County of Cook services or benefits on matters related to
citizenship; and

44

 JOURNAL OF PROCEEDINGS FOR SEPTEMBER 7, 2006

BE IT FURTHER RESOLVED, that requiring, or promoting, local enforcement of immigration laws
gives rise to an increased threat of immigrant and minority profiling and harassment and, therefore, it is
the policy of the Cook County Sheriffs Office not to become involved in the enforcement of federal civil
immigration laws to the extent legally possible; and
BE IT FURTHER RESOLVED, that the U.S. Department of Homeland Security and the U.S.
Immigration and Customs Enforcement be called upon to issue a moratorium on raids until the U.S.
Congress comes to an agreement on comprehensive immigration refonn so that the debate can be carried
out in good faith, rather than against a backdrop of fear, repression and intimidation; and
BE IT FURTHER RESOLVED, that the County of Cook rejects the use of the word " illegal" to
describe human beings and the use of the word "aliens" to describe immigrants, which has a
dehumanizing effect and helps justify policies that seek to criminalize and exclude immigrants, and
hereby adopts the language " undocumented" when referring to those who do not have federally
recognized resident status and "immigrant" to refer to those who have migrated to the U.S. from another
country; and
BE IT FURTHER RESOLVED, that the Cook County Board of Commissioners reaffirms its official
support earlier this year of private bill HR 3856, the Family Unity Act, which protects 35 Illinois families
from being tom apart by our broken immigration laws, and reaffirms its official support in 2005 of "The
Secure America Act" which allows families to be reunited more quickly through the family immigration
system; and
BE IT FURTHER RESOLVED, that a copy of this Resolution be submitted to the Illinois
Congressional delegation and to President George Bush on behalf of the entire Cook County Board.

Commissioner Moreno, seconded by Commissioner Silvestri, moved to suspend the rules so that this
matter may be considered. The motion carried unanimously.
Commissioner Maldonado, seconded by Commissioner Sims, moved that the Proposed Resolution be
referred to the Committee on Law Enforcement and Corrections. (Comm. No. 281408). The motion
carried unanimously.

ADULT PROBATION DEPARTMENT
GRANT AWARD RENEWAL
Transmitting a Communication, dated July 7, 2006 from
TIMOTHY C. EV ANS, Chief Judge, Circuit Court of Cook County
requesting authorization to renew a grant in the amount of $238,532.00 from the Illinois Department of
Human Services (IDHS). This grant will fund the program in the Adult Probation Department Mental
Health Unit that provides intensive supervision and coordinates treatment services for probationers who
have learning and mental disabilities. The program helps to ensure these probationers receive maximum
opportunities to successfully complete probation.
This longstanding program is funded annually by IDHS . Funds will be used for salaries and fringe
benefits for three (3) staff probation officers assigned to the Mental Health Unit.

45

 JOURNAL OF PROCEEDINGS FOR SEPTEMBER 7, 2006

This grant does not require an application process; the funding is automatically renewed.
The authorization to accept the previous grant was given on September 8, 2005 by the Cook County
Board of Commissioners in the amount of $23 1,585.00.
The Budget Department has reviewed this item, and all requisite documents have been submitted.
Estimated Fiscal Impact: None. Grant Award: $238,532.00. Funding period: July 1, 2006 through June
30, 2007.

Commissioner Maldonado, seconded by Commissioner Murphy, moved that the request of the Chief
Judge of the Circuit Court of Cook County be approved. The motion carried unanimously.

Commissioner Maldonado, seconded by Commissioner Butler, moved to ratify the action previously
taken with respect to the request of the Chief Judge of the Circuit Court of Cook County. The motion
carried.
Commissioner Gorman voted "no".

OFFICE OF THE COUNTY ASSESSOR
GRANT A WARD ADDENDUM
Transmitting a Communication, dated August I 8, 2006 from
JAMES M. HOULIHAN, Cook County Assessor
requesting authorization to accept a grant extension from July I, 2006 through June 30, 2008 from the
lllinois Department of Commerce and Economic Opportunity (DCEO) for the South Suburban Tax
Reactivation Program (SSTRP). This will enable SSTRP to expend the remaining grant funds. There
will be no estimated fiscal impact and will not require any further grant award monies.
The purpose of the SSTRP is to address the economic problems that afflict many of the southern Cook
County municipalities. The goal of the project is to get as many of these tax delinquent properties as
possible back on the tax rolls using the County "No Cash Bid" process to acquire these properties and
land bank them for future economic development. I am also requesting that the authority previously
granted Enterpriz Cook County to serve as fiscal agent for the SSTRP be extended through June 30, 2008.
The Budget Department has reviewed this item, and all requisite documents have been submitted.
Estimated Fiscal Impact: None. Funding period extension: July 1, 2006 through June 30, 2008.

Commissioner Maldonado, seconded by Commissioner Murphy, moved that the request of the Assessor
of Cook County be approved. The motion carried unanimously.

requesting authorization to apply fo r a grant in the amount of $3,5 I 0,000.00 from the Bureau of Justice
Assistance, U.S. Department of Justice. This grant, Office of Justice Programs - Automated Processing
of Bond Courts, will automate and integrate the processing of bond calls, so that the involved agencies
can verify that infonnation has been transmitted accurately, completely, and in a timely manner between
and among agencies.
The Budget Department has reviewed this item, and all requisite documents have been submitted.
Estimated Fiscal Impact: None. Grant Award:
through September 30, 2008.

* * * * *
Transmitting a Communication, dated August 16, 2006 from
DOROTHY BROWN, Clerk of the Circuit Court
requesting authorization to apply for a grant in the amount of $ 154,320.00 from the Bureau of Justice
Assistance, U.S. Department of Justice. This grant, National Criminal History Improvement Program "Smart Forms", will address record management of, and access to, data associated with and needed for
fireann pennitting to identify persons ineligible to purchase a firearm. In addition, this infonnation will
provide data to law enforcement personnel and others to ensure that persons with responsibility for child
care, elder care, and care of the disabled do not have disqualifying criminal records, are subject to
protection orders or are wanted for stalking and domestic violence.
The Budget Department has reviewed this item, and all requisite documents have been submitted.
Estimated Fiscal Impact: None. Grant Award: $ 154,320.00. Funding period: October I, 2006 through
September 30, 2007.

Commissioner Maldonado, seconded by Commissioner Murphy, moved that the request of the Clerk of
the Circuit Court be approved. The motion carried unanimously.

 JOURNAL OF PROCEEDINGS FOR SEPTEMBER 7, 2006

* * * * *
Transmitting a Communication, dated August 16, 2006 from
DOROTHY BROWN, Clerk of the Circuit Court
requesting authorization to apply for a grant in the amount of $300, 162.00 from the Bureau of Justice
Assistance, U.S. Department of Justice. This grant, National Criminal History Improvement Program
Grant - Orders of Protection, will enhance the crime fighting and criminal justice capabilities of state and
local governments by improving the accuracy, utility and interstate accessibility of criminal history
records and enhancing records of protective orders involving domestic violence and stalking, sex offender
records, automated identification systems and other state and local systems supporting national records
systems and their use for criminal history background checks.
The Budget Department has reviewed this item, and all requisite documents have been submitted.
Estimated Fiscal Impact: None. Grant Award: $300, 162.00. Funding period: October 1, 2006 through
September 30, 2007.
Commissioner Maldonado, seconded by Commissioner Murphy, moved that the request of the Clerk of
the Circuit Court be approved. The motion carried unanimously.

funds to available funds in the appropriation for the office as follows:

59

 JOURNAL OF PROCEEDINGS FOR SEPTEMBER 7, 2006

From: 786-260
To:
715/335-579
Reason:

Professional Services and Managerial Services
Major Capital Equipment Request

$350,000.00
$350,000.00

On April 8, 2004, the Board of Commissioners authorized entering into a contract with
NxLight Government Solutions, Inc. of Lindon, Utah (Item #24),. This project is part of the
work necessary to support the various processes and data exchange of critical criminal
information throughout the Cook County Justice Enterprise.
At the time of contract award, the funding for the $350,000.00 contract was to be provided by
a grant from the Illinois Criminal Justice Information Authority (ICJIA). However, ICJIA has
now indicated that funds will not be approved. This contract is critical to improving the
exchange of criminal information among County agencies and the fulfillment of the overall
plans envisioned by the Cook County Integrated Justice Information Steering Committee.

Estimated Fiscal Impact: $350,000.00. One time purchase. (715/335-579 Account).
Sufficient funds have been appropriated to cover this request.

This item was WITHDRAWN at the request of the sponsor.

Request for Proposals (RFP) sought, J.J. Collins Sons, Inc. was the lowest, qualified
respondent to meet all requirements.

WAIVER OF THE PROVISIONS OF THE COUNTY'S MBE/WBE ORDINANCE
The following item was previously approved by poll on July 28, 2006:
Transmitting a Communication, dated July 19, 2006 from
DAYID ORR, County Clerk
by
BRANDON NEESE, Deputy County Clerk
Re: Contract No. 06-84-347
It is respectfully requested that this honorable body approve this request that a waiver be granted to
permit the award of the above-referenced contract, despite the sole-bidder's failure to fu lly comply with
the County's Ordinance on minority participation.

Obtaining the warrant and judgment book covers immediately is required in order to make 2004 tax
records available for public inspection, as required by law. The public, title companies, and other real
estate professionals use the records. Having them available for public inspection is essential.
The item has been sent out for bid twice, and any further delay will seriously jeopardize the public's
access to necessary information.
In accordance with Rule-4-2(c), the vote on the poll taken July 28, 2006 is as follows: 14 Yeas; 2 Nays
(Commissioners Collins and Maldonado); and I Excused Absence (President Stroger).
Commissioner Hansen, seconded by Commissioner Silvestri, moved to ratify the action previously taken
with respect to the request of the Deputy County Clerk. The motion carried unanimously.

 JOURNAL OF PROCEEDINGS FOR SEPTEMBER 7, 2006

BUREAU OF HEALTH SERVICES
GRANT A WARD RENEW AL

Transmitting a Communication, dated June 29, 2006 from
DANIEL H. WINSHIP, M.D., Chief, Bureau of Health Services
requesting authorization to renew a grant in the amount of $1 , 196,400.00 from the Illinois Department of
Human Services (IDHS), for the Supplemental Nutrition Program for Women, Infants and Children
(WIC) and Family Planning Services.
The Supplemental Nutrition Program for Women, Infants and Children (WIC) grant is to provide health
screening, supplemental food certification, food, prescription and nutrition counseling services to women,
infants, and children. The grant award is in the amount of$574,700.00.
The Family Planning Services program affords women the opportunity to voluntarily choose a method of
birth control. The grant award is in the amount of $62 1,700.00.
The authorization to accept the previous grants was given on September 8, 2005 by the Cook County
Board of Commissioners in the amount of $562,500.00 for the Supplemental Nutrition Program for
Women, Infants and Children (WIC) grant and for the Family Planning Services grant in the amount of
$601 ,700.00.
These grants do not require an application process; the funding is automatically renewed.
The Budget Department has reviewed this item, and all requisite documents have been submitted.
Estimated Fiscal Impact: None. Total Grant Award: $1, 196,400.00. Funding period: July I , 2006
through June 30, 2007.

Commissioner Maldonado, seconded by Commissioner Murphy, moved that the request of the Chief of
the Bureau of Health Services be approved. The motion carried unanimously.

14,867,000.00
22,78 1,056.00
504,000.00
$ 319,429,744.33

70

 JOURNAL OF PROCEEDINGS FOR SEPTEMBER 7, 2006

Reason:

The Patient Medication Assistance Services Program began in mid-2002, and has been
conducted to date by McKesson Medication Management, one of the few finns in the industry
that provides these services. McKesson Medication Management provides these services
pursuant to a subcontract with McKesson Corporation under the subject contract.
While the County has identified, through the competitive bid process, a new prime vendor, a
contractor has yet to be identified to continue the Patient Medication Assistance Program
Services currently provided by McKesson Medication Management. A bid was issued for
these Patient Medication Assistance Program Services, but it has recently been detennined
that it will be recommended that the Patient Medication Assistance Program contract be rebid
with revised specifications.
Since McKesson Medication Management currently has infrastructure and trained staff in
place to provide these Medication Assistance Services, and since a service gap will occur if
the current contract with McKesson expires as to these services without a transition to a
replacement contract, it is recommended the County extend Contract No. 02-43-960, only as it
pertains to the Medication Assistance Program Services, for a period of four (4) months. This
extension will pennit the Bureau to work with the Purchasing Agent to rebid the Patient
Medication Assistance Services contract, with revised specifications.

Estimated Fiscal Impact: $504,000.00 [$80,000.00 - (240-36 1 Account); $32,000.00 - (891-36 1
Account); $360,000.00 - (897-361 Account); and $32,000.00 - (898-361 Account)). Contract extension:
August 1, 2006 through November 30, 2006.
In accordance with Rule 4-2(c), the vote on the poll taken on July 28, 2006 is as follows: 16 Yeas; 0
Nays; I Excused Absence (President Stroger).
Commissioner Maldonado, seconded by Commissioner Butler, moved to ratify, as amended the action
previously taken with respect to the request of the Chief of the Bureau of Health Services. The motion
carried unanimously.

CONTRACT RENEWALS
Transmitting a Communication dated August 17, 2006 from
WALLY S. KOS, P.E., Superintendent of Highways
Re: Contract Renewal
Electrical and Mechanical Item Maintenance
Various locations in Cook County
Section: 07-8EMIM-35-GM
I respectfully recommend that your Honorable Body approve a renewal for one ( I) year, the contract for
Electrical and Mechanical Item Maintenance - 2006 known as Section : 06-8EMIM-34-GM between
Meade Electric Company, Inc., McCook, Illinois and the County of Cook.
The contract is for the maintenance of (I) traffic signal intersections, (2) street and roadway lighting
systems, (3) navigation lighting systems, bridge cathodic protection systems, (4) storm water pumping
station systems, and (5) maintenance facilities electrical systems and their appurtenances, located in Cook
County.
The Contractor, for specified unit prices listed under schedule of prices, shall: (I) furnish all labor and
provide materials to maintain the respective installations and systems, in first class working order and
operating condition at all times, (2) make permanent repairs to damaged equipment, (3) clean, repair,
perfonn preventative maintenance, and overhaul specified equipment at stated intervals of time, (4)
provide the necessary transportation for workmen, materials, and equipment used to execute the terms of
the contract, (5) provide continuous maintenance and repair service, including Saturdays, Sundays and
holidays to correct any malfunction of equipment or effect any temporary emergency repairs to missing,
defective, displaced or damaged equipment resulting from any cause in the shortest possible time, (6)
patrol and inspect the respective systems for lamp and other failures and non-operative equipment, shall
replace electric lamps in all systems as required, and (7) execute specialty items for unit prices as directed
by the engineer, and perfonn all activities required in the amount of$1 ,877,077.00.

73

 JOURNAL OF PROCEEDINGS FOR SEPTEMBER 7, 2006

The contract was competitively bid on November 8, 2005 with two (2) contractors submi tting proposals.
Award of the contract was approved by the County Board on December 6, 2005. The contract included a
provision that allowed the County to renew the contract for an additional year at the same unit prices if
the County was satisfied with their perfonnance and quality of work.
Therefore, this renewal recommendation is made pursuant to the provision in Article V, Duration of
Contract, extension on page 322 of the current contract which expires on December 31, 2006.
Estimated Fiscal Impact: $1,877,077.00. Contract period: January 1, 2007 through December 31, 2007.
Motor Fuel Tax Fund (600-600 Account).
Approval of this item would commit Fiscal Year 2007 funds.

Commissioner Hansen, seconded by Commissioner Goslin, moved that the County Purchasing Agent be

Re: Contract Renewal
Sign Panel Assembly Maintenance - 2006
Countywide
Section: 06-8SPAM-27-GM
I respectfully recommend that your Honorable Body approve a renewal for one ( I) year, the contract for

Lites, Inc., Addison, Illinois and the County of Cook.
This maintenance contract consists of furnishing, removing, relocating and maintaining existing and new
sign panel assemblies and their appurtenances on various roads in Cook County.

Board on January 18, 2006 in the amount of $397,200.00. The contract included a provision that allowed
the County to renew the contract for an additional year at the same unit prices if we were satisfied with
the contractor's performance and quality of work. A Letter of Mutual Concurrence between the Highway
Department and Barricade Lites, Inc. for the contract renewal has been submitted.
Therefore, this renewal recommendation is made pursuant to the provisions in the Duration of Contract
section of the current contract which expires on December 31, 2006. If you concur in this
recommendation, the contract extension into 2007 will be identified and funded as Section: 07-8SPAM28-GM.

Motor Fuel Tax Fund (600-600 Account) .
Approval of this item would commit Fiscal Year 2007 funds.

Commissioner Hansen, seconded by Commissioner Goslin, moved that the County Purchasing Agent be
authorized to renew the requested contract. The motion carried unanimously.

RESOLUTIONS
Transmitting a Communication, dated August 16, 2006 from
WALLY S. KOS, P .E., Superintendent of Highways
Letter of Agreement between the County of Cook and the Village of Frankfort
Advance tree replacement
Harlem A venue,
South of Sauk Trail to Lincoln Highway (US 30)
in the Village of Frankfort in County Board District #6
Section: 06-W3502-02-RP
Centerline Mileage: 1.38 miles
Fiscal Impact: $160,000.00 from the Motor Fuel Tax Fund (600-600 Account)
06-R-317
RESOLUTION
RESOLVED, by the Members of the Board of Commissioners of Cook County, Illinois, on behalf of the
County of Cook, to authorize and direct its President to execute, by original signature or her authorized
signature stamp, two (2) copies of a Letter of Agreement, submitted, with the Village of Frankfort,
wherein the Village will be the lead agency/coordinator for an advance tree planting contract along the
west side of Harlem Avenue (County Highway W35) as mitigation for future tree removals resulting from
the County's proposed future improvements along Harlem Avenue from south of Sauk Trail to Lincoln
Highway (US 30), as a condition of the Village's expressed support for said improvements; that the
County of Cook shall reimburse the Village of Frankfort for replacement trees planted by the Village on
private property as mitigation for future extensive tree removals as part of the improvements to be
identified as Cook County Section: 06-W3502-02-RP, County reimbursement cost not to exceed
$160,000.00; and, the Highway Department is authorized and directed to return an executed copy of this
Resolution with Agreement to the Village of Frankfort.
September 7, 2006

Commissioner Hansen, seconded by Commissioner Goslin, moved that the Resolution be approved and
adopted. The motion carried unanimously.

89

 JOURNAL OF PROCEEDINGS FOR SEPTEMBER 7, 2006

* * * * *
Transmitting a Communication, dated August 14, 2006 from
WALLY S. KOS, P.E., Superintendent of Highways
Traffic Signal Maintenance and Energy Agreement between the County of Cook and the Village of
Northbrook
Revised responsibilities and cost sharing for maintenance and energy of an existing traffic signal
Sunset Ridge Road at Skokie Road
in the Village of Northbrook in County Board District # 14
Fiscal Impact: $1,200.00 (75% reimbursable by the Village) from the Motor Fuel Tax Fund (600-600
Account)
06-R-318
RESOLUTION

RESOLVED, by the Members of the Board of Commissioners of Cook County, Illinois, on behalf of the
County of Cook, to authorize and direct its President to execute, by original signature or her authorized
signature stamp, two (2) copies of a Traffic Signal Maintenance and Energy Agreement with the Village
of Northbrook for the existing traffic signal at the intersection of Sunset Ridge Road at Skokie Road,
wherein the County shall assume ownership and operate and maintain the traffic signal upon execution of
this agreement by the County; that the Village agrees to pay the County seventy-five percent (75%) of the
maintenance charges of the traffic signal, assume seventy-five percent (75%) of the electrical energy
charges of the traffic signal and agrees to pay for maintenance, repair and/or replacement costs for the
existing Emergency Vehicle Pre-emptive Device (EVPD) System; and, that the Highway Department is
authorized and directed to return one (1) executed copy of this Resolution and Agreement to the Village
of Northbrook to evidence the formal Agreement hereby resulting and to be bound by the terms thereof
on behalf of the County.

September 7, 2006

Commissioner Hansen, seconded by Commissioner Goslin, moved that the Resolution be approved and
adopted. The motion carried unanimously.

in the Village of Willow Springs in County Board District #16
Section: 05-W22 I 9-04-TL

Account)

90

 JOURNAL OF PROCEEDINGS FOR SEPTEMBER 7, 2006

06-R-319
RESOLUTION
RESOLVED, by the Members of the Board of Commissioners of Cook County, Illinois, on behalf of the
County of Cook to authorize and direct its President to execute, by original signature or her authorized
signature stamp, two (2) copies of an Agreement with the Village of Willow Springs, wherein the County
will install an Emergency Vehicle Pre-emptive Device (EVPD) system at the intersection of Wolf Road at
Gennan Church Road, with the Village of Willow Springs to pay one hundred percent (100%) of the cost
for said EVPD system (estimated construction cost $6,000.00) following acceptance of the completed
project; and, the Highway Department is directed to return one ( 1) copy of this Resolution with
Agreement to the Village of Willow Springs to evidence the formal Agreement hereby resulting and to be
bound by the terms thereof on behalf of the County.

WALLY S. KOS, P.E., Superintendent of Highways
Tiered Approach to Corrective Action Objectives Agreement
Shell Oil Products US
4801 West Sauk Trail (CH Cl I) at Cicero Avenue
in the Village of Richton Park in County Board District #6
Fiscal Impact: None
06-R-320
RESOLUTION
RESOLVED, by the Members of the Board of Commissioners of Cook County, Illinois, on behalf of the
County of Cook, to authorize and direct its President to execute, by original signature or her authorized
signature stamp, three (3) copies of a TIERED APPROACH TO CORRECTJVE ACTJON OBJECTIVES
(TACO) AGREEMENT with Shell Oil Products US, submitted herewith and made part hereof, wherein,
on highways under Cook County jurisdiction, adjacent to Shell Oil Products US owned facilities and
subject to said Tiered Approach Agreement, the County of Cook shall prohibit the extraction of potable
water from its right-of-way and shall notify Pennittees of proscribed status and requirements at the
following location as part of its Highway Department Permit process.
RESOLVED, that the following location is approved as being subject to TIERED APPROACH TO
CORRECTIVE ACTION OBJECTIVES (TACO) AGREEMENT:

4801 West Sauk Trail (CH C l I) at Cicero Avenue in the Village of Richton Park
RESOLVED, and accepted; that Shell Oil Products US indemnifies and holds the County of Cook
harmless from damages and liabilities arising from the presence of contaminants in County of Cook rightof-way and accepted; that the procedure for the County of Cook to be reimbursed for costs incurred
should, in the course of nonnal highway maintenance, the County of Cook be required to excavate and
dispose of contaminated soils.

Devon Avenue at Tonne Road/Wood Dale Road
in the Village of Elk Grove in County Board District # 17
Section: 01-Bl I 15-05-CH

Grove will be the lead agency for construction of the improvement and the County will share the costs of
construction and construction engineering. This amendment increases the County's participatory share of
costs (30% local match) for construction, not to exceed $428,339.00, and construction engineering, not to
exceed $43,242.00 (originally estimated at $288,750.00 and $39,555.00, respectively) and provides for
reimbursement to the Village of Elk Grove for said additional costs (estimated total increase $143,276.00)
that were not anticipated in the original Agreement under Section: 01-Bl 115-05-CH.

actions called for under the terms of the Amendment and is further directed to return one (1) executed

JUDICIAL ADVISORY COUNCIL
GRANT AW ARDS
The following item was previously approved by poll on August 18, 2006:

Transmitting a Communication, dated August 3, 2006 from
DANIEL J. COUGHLIN, Executive Director, Judicial Advisory Council
approval is hereby requested of the Notice of Grant Agreement between the Illinois Emergency
Management Agency (IEMA) and the County of Cook. This agreement for federal fiscal year 2006
Urban Area Security Initiative funding provides Cook County with $13,065,000.00. These funds require
no County match.

102

 JOURNAL OF PROCEEDINGS FOR SEPTEMBER 7, 2006

This plan has been prepared in accordance with the guidelines established by the United States
Department of Homeland Security. These funds will provide for a continuation of the installation of the
state-of-art interoperable wireless communication system and the initial phase of the installation of a
County-wide interoperable radio communication system to be used by emergency responders throughout
Cook County.
The authorization to accept the 2005 grant was given on September 20, 2005 by the Cook County Board
of Commissioners in the amount of $22,465,000.00 with no required cash match.
Permission is hereby requested for the Executive Director of the Judicial Advisory Council to enter into
agreements with the Sheriff, other Cook County agencies, political subdivisions of Cook County and nonprofit agencies with respect to the distribution of these funds and the activities required to implement the
programs funded through the grant which is part of the Cook County Urban Area Security Initiative
known as the Cook County Shield Project.
I respectfully request that the Executive Director of the Cook County Judicial Advisory Council, or his
designee, on behalf of Cook County, be authorized to execute any and all necessary documents to further
the project approval therein, including, but not limited to, the subgrantee agreement and any modification
thereto.
This grant does not require an application process.
The Budget Department has reviewed this item, and all requisite documents have been submitted.
Estimated Fiscal Impact: None. Grant Award: $13,065 ,000 .00. Funding period: Date of Final
Execution by the Granter (Illinois Emergency Management Agency) through March 31, 2008.
In accordance with Rule 4-2(c), the vote on the poll taken on August 18, 2006 is as follows: 14 Yeas; 0
Nays; and 2 Absent (Commissioners Butler ·and Sims).

Commissioner Maldonado, seconded by Commissioner Murphy, moved to ratify the action previously
taken with respect to the request of the Executive Director of the Judicial Advisory Council. The motion
carried unanimously.

* * * * *
The following item was previously approved by poll on August 18, 2006:
Transmitting a Communication, dated August 3, 2006 from
DANIEL J. COUGHLIN, Executive Director, Judicial Advisory Council
approval is hereby requested of the Notice of Grant Agreement between the Illinois Emergency
Management Agency (IEMA) and the County of Cook. This second agreement for federal fiscal year
2004 Urban Area Security Initiative funding provides Cook County with $16, 110,714.64. The grant
agreement was necessitated because the State of Illinois did not process on a timely basis the County' s
request to extend the previously approved 2004 grant. Including the funds of the grant agreement which
tenninated on May 31 , 2006, and the above proposed grant agreement, a total of $ 16,869,672.00 will have
been allocated to Cook County for the federal fiscal year 2004 Urban Area Security Initiative. These
funds require no County match.

103

 JOURNAL OF PROCEEDINGS FOR SEPTEMBER 7, 2006

This plan has been prepared in accordance with the guidelines established by the United States
Department of Homeland Security. These funds will provide for a continuation of the installation of the
state-of-art interoperable wireless communication system to be used by emergency responders throughout
Cook County, the purchasing and staging of medical supplies and equipment, assessment and hardening
of critical infrastructures and the training and exercising of emergency responders from throughout Cook
County.
The authorization to accept the 2004 grant was given on October 4, 2004 by the Cook County Board of
Commissioners in the amount of $16,869,672.00 with no required cash match.
Permission is hereby requested for the Executive Director of the Judicial Advisory Council to enter into
agreements with the Sheriff, other Cook County agencies, political subdivisions of Cook County and nonprofit agencies with respect to the distribution of these funds and the activities required to implement the
programs funded through the grant which is part of the Cook County Urban Area Security Initiative
known as the Cook County Shield Project.
I respectfully request that the Executive Director of the Cook County Judicial Advisory Council, or his
designee, on behalf of Cook County, be authorized to execute any and all necessary documents to further
the project approval therein, including, but not limited to, the subgrantee agreement and any modification
thereto.
This grant does not require an application process.
The Budget Department has reviewed this item, and all requisite documents have been submitted.
Estimated Fiscal Impact: None. Grant Award: $16,110,714.64. Funding period: July 1, 2005 through
November 30, 2006.
In accordance with Rule 4-2(c), the vote on the poll taken on August 18, 2006 is as follows: 14 Yeas; 0
Nays; and 2 Absent (Commissioners Butler and Sims).

Commissioner Maldonado, seconded by Commissioner Murphy, moved to ratify the action previously
taken with respect to the request of the Executive Director of the Judicial Advisory Council. The motion
carried unanimously.

HOME INVESTMENT PARTNERSHIPS PROGRAM
Transmitting a Communication, dated August 16, 2006 from
PETER C. NICHOLSON, Director, Department of Planning and Development
Re:

American Dream Down Payment Initiative (ADDI)
HOME Investment Partnerships Program (HOME Program)

respectfully request approval of an American Dream Down Payment Initiative (ADDI) Program grant to
Northwest Housing Partnerships Program, from funds allocated through the HOME Investment
Partnerships Program. Funds will be used to provide closing costs and down payment assistance to
approximately forty (40) low-income first-time home buyers to purchase single-family housing that will
serve as the families' principal residence.
The ADDI Program grant of $400,000.00 will be made between Northwest Housing Partnership (NWHP)
and the County of Cook. NWHP has previously been a successfully participant with HOME Program and
CDBG funds .

108

 JOURNAL OF PROCEEDINGS FOR SEPTEMBER 7, 2006

Approval of this grant will enable NWHP to expand home ownership opportunities for income-eligible
households and to increase homeownership within Cook County. ADDI funds, not exceeding $10,000.00
or 6% of the purchase price (whichever is greater) per household, will be provided to income qualified
persons. Funds are provided as a five-year-zero-interest forgiveable loan, which is secured by a note and
mortgage subordinate to those of the primary lenders.
I respectfully request approval of this project and that the Chief Administrative Officer of the County of
Cook, or his designee, be authorized to execute on behalf of the County of Cook, any and all documents
necessary to further the project approved herein, including, but not limited to the Subgrantee Agreement
and any modifications thereto. The necessary documents will be reviewed and approved by the State' s
Attorney 's Office. Approval of this grant by this Honorable Body will pennit staff to move forward with
this project.
Fiscal Impact: None. Grant Funds: $400,000.00. (772-298 Account).

Commissioner Collins, seconded by Commissioner Murphy, moved that the request of the Director of the
Department of Planning and Development be approved. The motion carried unanimously.
PROPOSED RESOLUTION

Transmitting a Communication, dated August 14, 2006 from
PETER C. NICHOLSON, Director, Department of Planning and Development
Re:

Hadady Corporation
Resolution Approving Class 8 for new construction in unincorporated Cook

respectfully submitting this Resolution regarding the company' s application for a Class 8 property tax
incentive for your consideration.
Hadady Corporation requests approval of the Class 8 incentive for new construction in the unincorporated
area of Bloom Township. This Resolution is required so that the company can complete its application to
the Assessor of Cook County.
Hadady Corporation's application for a Class 8, and a Department of Planning and Development staff
report have been submitted for your information.
PROPOSED RESOLUTION
WHEREAS, the Cook County Board of Commissioners has adopted a Real Property Assessment
Classification 8 that provides an applicant a reduction in the assessment level for an industrial facility;
and
WHEREAS, the County Board of Commissioners has received and reviewed an application from
Hadady Corporation for new construction in unincorporated Bloom Township at 21825 East Lincoln
Highway, Lynwood, Cook County, Illinois, Property Index Numbers 33-29-200-011-0000 and 33-29200-012-0000; and
WHEREAS, the County Board has determined that the Class 8 is necessary for development to occur on
the subject property and beneficial to the local economy.

109

 JOURNAL OF PROCEEDINGS FOR SEPTEMBER 7, 2006

NOW, THEREFORE, BE IT RESOLVED, by the President and Board of Commissioners of the
County of Cook, State of Illinois, that the President and Board of Commissioners find that Hadady
Corporation' s industrial use of the property is necessary and beneficial to the local economy and that they
support and consent to the application for a Class 8 for new construction in unincorporated Bloom
Township at 21825 East Lincoln Highway, Lynwood, Cook County, Illinois; and
BE IT FURTHER RESOLVED, that the County Clerk is hereby authorized and directed to forward a
certified copy of this Resolution to the Office of the Cook County Assessor.

Commissioner Collins, seconded by Commissioner Quigley, moved that the Proposed Resolution be
referred to the Committee on Business and Economic Development. (Comm. No. 281394). The motion
carried unanimously.

CONTRACT
Transmitting a Communication from
JOHN A. FAIRMAN, SR., Chief Operating Officer, Provident Hospital of Cook County
requesting authorization for the Purchasing Agent to enter into a contract with Automed Technologies,
Inc., Vernon Hills, Illinois, for the purchase of a phannacy automation system.
Reason:

Automed Technologies, Inc. is the manufacturer and only authorized source for the Optifill II
phannacy automation system. The Optifill II is the only system that provides automated
capping for robotically filled oral solid medications, automated patient order collation,
automated patient order routing, automated order initiation, image capture of all robotically
filled prescriptions for comparison to reference images, and the ability for operators to
overwrite, or create new reference images. This system has the ability to process up to 200
automatically filled bottles per hour, and an overall system capacity of up to 1,800
prescriptions per shift.

 JOURNAL OF PROCEEDINGS FOR SEPTEMBER 7, 2006

Estimated Fiscal Impact: $693,812.00. One time purchase. (717/891-540 Account). Requisition No.
68910543.

DEPARTMENT OF RISK MANAGEMENT
PROPOSED CONTRACT AMENDMENT
Transmitting a Communication, dated August I 6, 2006 from
JOHN L. HIBBETT, Director, Department of Risk Management
requesting to amend prior authorization to enter into a contract with Advent Medical Management,
Chicago, Illinois, Risk Management Solutions of America, Chicago, Illinois and Spectrum Health
Services, Inc., Bolingbrook, Illinois, which was Board approved on December 14, 2004 as Item Number
34, to provide an integrated Workers' Compensation case management program designed to contain costs
and accelerate the return to work process for injured employees on a pilot program basis. The contract
establishes a pilot program to achieve savings and improved service in administering workers'
compensation claims.
The original Board letter provided for a contract amount of$ I 35,000.00, reflecting only certain start-up
costs and an annual charge for the two-year operation of a "call center" by Ri sk Management Solutions of
America, where the initial intake of claimant infonnation is obtained. While the program was also
intended to include the perfonnance of certain case investigation services, case management services and
bill review services by Spectrum Health Services and Advent Medical Management, the original Board
authorization did not clarify the respective services to be provided by each finn . In addition, it did not
include the basis for payment of these finns because the amounts payable for these services are billed
directly to the applicable case file paid from the (542-845 Account) Self Insurance Fund, Self Insurance
Settlements and Worker' s Compensation. Pay ments from this account are typically smaller amounts
which are not required to be presented to the Board and are routinely made as part of the administration of
workers' compensation benefits. However, in working on this contract, the State's Attorney requested
that we amend the contract authorization to detail the basis for payment of these case-by case services and
to allocate the services to be provided by contractor so that the contract better matches the Board's
authorization.
The amounts payable to Advent Medical Management for bill review services are $7 .50 per bill reviewed
by Advent, plus a percentage of savings ranging from 18% - 25% of the amount by which charges are
reduced. The estimated cumulative amount that could be payable from actual savings to Advent Medical
Management over the tenn of the contract is $625,000.00.
Amounts payable to Risk Management Services of America, Inc. for case investigation services, which
are in addition to call center services, are based on a rate of $25 per witness interview or statement on
claims investigated on the basis of pre-approved criteria up to a maximum of $75.00 (three contracts,
witness interviews or statements) per claim . The estimated cumulative amount that could be payable to
Risk Management Solutions of America, Inc. for these services is $20,000.00.

117

 JOURNAL OF PROCEEDINGS FOR SEPTEMBER 7, 2006

Finally, case management services provided by Spectrum Health Services, Inc., which are the more
specialized services in this program, are provided at the rate of $85.00 per hour for cases that were open
prior to the agreement and at a per file rate of $250.00 for the first 30 days after a matter is opened and
$175.00 for every 30 days of management thereafter. These services are also provided only if preapproved criteria are met. The intention is that they ultimately result in a reduction of the County's
payment obligations under its workers compensation program. The estimated cumulative amount which
could be payable to Spectrum Health Services, Inc. for these services is $60,000.00.
The cumulative amount payable for these services, in addition to the $135,000.00 previously referenced
for the call center operations, will be approximately $295,000.00 in Year 1 and $410,000.00 in Year 2.
As noted above, these amounts will be paid in small increments associated with individual case files . The
actual amount payable may be less, depending upon the actual usage of the services offered.
The pilot program, to date, has resulted in savings to the County of $1,418,910.98. It is the intent of the
Department of Risk Management to issue a Request for Proposal (RFP) to ensure the continued
competitiveness of the costs associated with the program.
Estimated Fiscal Impact: $840,000.00. (Year 1: $135,000.00 - $295,000.00 for start up cost; Year 2:
$410,000.00 total annual call center fee). Contract period: February 1, 2005 through January 31, 2007.
(542-845 Account).

This item was WITHDRAWN at the request of the sponsor.

OFFICE OF THE STATE'S ATTORNEY
GRANT A WARD ADDENDUM
Transmitting a Communication, dated August 7, 2006 from
DENNIS MANZKE, Chief of the Administrative Services Bureau, State's Attorney 's Office
requesting authorization to accept a no-cost grant extension from the U.S. Department of Justice
(USDOJ), Office of Juvenile Justice and Delinquency Prevention for the Cook County Internet Crimes
Against Children (ICAC) Task Force Program. This extension will enable the office to expend the entire
award amount as well as accomplish all of the program goals and objectives. This grant provides funding
to equip and train the Cook County ICAC Task Force partner agencies in an effort to aggressively
identify, investigate and prosecute persons who use the Internet to sexually exploit children. The Cook
County ICAC Task Force partners include representatives of the State's Attorney's Office, the Chicago
Police Department and law enforcement agencies from each of the five suburban Municipal Districts.
Task Force partners from local law enforcement agencies will concentrate their investigative efforts in the
City of Chicago and the entire outlying suburban Cook County area.
The authorization to accept the original grant was given on July 12, 2005 by the Cook County Board of
Commissioners in the amount of $100,000.00.
The Budget Department has reviewed this item, and all requisite documents have been submitted.
Estimated Fiscal Impact: None. Funding period extension: August I, 2006 through July 31 , 2007.

Commissioner Maldonado, seconded by Commissioner Murphy, moved that the request of the Chief of
the Administrative Services Bureau of the State's Attorney's Office be approved. The motion carried
unanimously.

122

 JOURNAL OF PROCEEDINGS FOR SEPTEMBER 7, 2006

GRANT AW ARD RENEWALS

Transmitting a Communication, dated August 3, 2006 from
DENNIS MANZKE, Chief of the Administrative Services Bureau, State' s Attorney' s Office
requesting authorization to renew a grant in the amount of $39, I00.00 from the Illinois Department of
Children and Family Services (IDCFS). This grant will provide continued partial funding for the child
sexual abuse specialist program that is jointly funded by the Illinois Attorney General' s Office. The one
(I) full time child sexual abuse specialist funded by this grant focuses on providing victim services
including crisis intervention with victims and families of victims, identifying and making referrals for
immediate and long-term counseling services, monitoring and coordinating services for children who are
wards of the state and working with the local and state agencies involved with the victim as well as
working directly with local and state law enforcement and service agencies to provide training, technical
assistance and consultation. The estimated fiscal impact is the remaining salary and fringe benefits of the
child sexual abuse specialist that would not be covered by the anticipated grant awards for the Illinois
Attorney General's Office and the Illinois Department of Children and Family Services. (See related Item
#58).
The authorization to apply for this grant was given on March 15, 2006 by the Cook County Board of
Commissioners in the amount of $39, 100.00.
The Budget Department has reviewed this item, and all requisite documents have been submitted.
Estimated Fiscal Impact: $35,807.00. Grant Award: $39, I00.00. Funding period: July I, 2006 through
June 30, 2007. (250-818 Account).

Commissioner Maldonado, seconded by Commissioner Murphy, moved that the request of the Chief of
the Administrative Services Bureau of the State's Attorney' s Office be approved. The motion carried
unanimously.

* * * * *

requesting authorization to accept a grant renewal in the amount of $20,531.00 from the lllinois Attorney
General' s Office. This grant will provide continued partial funding for the Child Sexual Abuse Specialist
Program that is jointly funded by the Illinois Attorney General's Office and the Illinois Department of
Children and Family Services (IDCFS). The one (I) full-time child sexual abuse specialist funded by this
grant focuses on providing victim services including crisis intervention with victims and families of
victims, identifying and making referrals for immediate and long-tenn counseling services, monitoring
and coordinating services for children who are wards of the state and working with the local and state
agencies involved with the victim as well as working directly with local and state Jaw enforcement and
service agencies to provide training, technical assistance and consultation. (See related Item #57).

Commissioners in the amount of $25,531.00.

CAPITAL CRIMES LITIGATION TRUST FUND PROGRAM

Transmitting a Communication, dated August 9, 2006 from
ADRIENNE D. MEBANE, ChiefofStaff, State' s Attorney's Office
requesting authorization to renew a program in the amount of $2,691,200.00 from the State of Illinois
pursuant to the Capital Crimes Litigation Act (725 ILCS 124). This Act created the Capital Litigation
Trust Fund to provide additional resources to both prosecutors and defense attorneys working on potential
capital cases. Pursuant to the Act, funding is provided annually to the State's Attorney's Office through
June 30, 2008 and is to be used for expenses necessary to prosecute capital cases.
This program does not require a cash match.
The authorization to accept the previous funding of this program was given on December 6, 2005 by the
Cook County Board of Commissioners in the amount of$2,691,200.00.
The Budget Department has reviewed this item, and all requisite documents have been submitted.
Estimated Fiscal Impact: None. Program Funding Amount: $2,691,200.00. Funding period: July 1,
2006 through June 30, 2007.
Commissioner Maldonado, seconded by Commissioner Sims, moved that the request of the Chief of Staff
of the State' s Attorney's Office be approved. The motion carried unanimously.

BAD CHECK DIVERSION PROGRAM
Transmitting a Communication, dated August 15, 2006 from
ADRIENNE D. MEBANE, Chief of Staff, State's Attorney' s Office
requesting pennission to establish a budget for the State' s Attorney ' s Bad Check Diversion Program in
the amount of $68,080.00. Pursuant to Public Act 93-0394, the State's Attorney is authorized to divert
from prosecution, on condition of making full restitution and completing an educational program, persons
charged with deceptive practices for writing bad checks. This program is funded by an administrative fee
collected from the offenders, and will be renewed annually subject to fees collected.
Estimated Fiscal Impact: None.

Commissioner Daley, seconded by Commissioner Silvestri, moved that the communication be referred to
the Committee on Finance. (Comm. No. 28 I 385). The motion carried unanimously.
