COOPERATIVE EDUCATIONAL MASTER AGREEMENT PROGRAM ADDENDA
Transmitting a Communication, dated June 26, 2006 from
JOHNNY C. BROWN, Chief Operating Officer, Stroger Hospital of Cook County
requesting authorization for the Cook County Board of Commissioners to amend the following item,
which was previously approved at the June 6, 2006 Board Meeting (Agenda Item #30), to reflect the most
recent authorization date and contract number of the Cooperative Educational Master Agreement. The
Program Addenda (Subagreement) and the new Cooperative Educational Master Agreement were
approved on the same date therefore the amended information was not available.
The stricken and underscored language indicates the amendment.

 JOURNAL OF PROCEEDINGS FOR SEPTEMBER 7, 2006

Transmitting a Communication, dated May 9, 2006 from
JOHNNY C. BROWN, Chief Operating Officer, Stroger Hospital of Cook County
requesting authorization for the Purchasing Agent to enter into a new Program Addenda (Subagreement)
to the Cooperative Educational Master Agreement (CEMA), for Orthopaedic Surgery and
Otolaryngology, Contract No. 95 43 l 017 06-41-561, as authorized by the County Board on September 6,
+9% June 6, 2006, with McGaw Medical Center of Northwestern University, Chicago, Illinois, for
Stroger Hospital of Cook County, Department of Surgery, Division of Orthopaedic Surgery and Division
of Otolaryngology.
The Program Addenda will combine the academic and clinical resources of McGaw Medical Center of
Northwestern University to the educational and training experience of Stroger Hospital of Cook County.
Pursuant to the Subagreement, McGaw Medical Center of Northwestern University will provide rotating
residents to include:
•

Two (2) FTE residents, PGY IV, shall be assigned concurrently to the Division of Orthopaedic
Surgery for three (3) month rotations each during the academic year.

•

Three (3) FTE residents, PGY Il-V, shall be assigned concurrently to the Division of
Otolaryngology so as to provide continuous coverage during the time periods covered by the
Program Addenda with rotations lasting three to six (3-6) months each.

CONTRACTS
Transmitting a Communication from
JOHNNY C. BROWN, Chief Operating Officer, Stroger Hospital of Cook County
requesting authorization for the Purchasing Agent to enter into a contract with Cynosure, Inc., Westford,
Massachusetts, for the purchase of a Cynergy™ pulse dye laser and long pulse Nd:Y AG laser modular
workstation for the Department of Medicine, Division of Dermatology.
Reason:

Cynosure, Inc. is the only known manufacturer and distributor of the Cynergy™ pulse dye
laser and long pulse Nd:YAG laser modular workstation for treatment of serious dermatologic
abnormalities such as vascular lesions, keloidal scarring, spider veins, unwanted hair and
court ordered tattoo removal.

Transmitting a Communication from
JOHNNY C. BROWN, Chief Operating Officer, Stroger Hospital of Cook County
requesting authorization for the Purchasing Agent to enter into a contract with Boston Scientific
Corporation, Maple Grove, Minnesota, for the purchase of Liberte™ coronary artery stents, the
Flextome™ Cutting Balloon® dilatation device, the Ultra2™ Monorail® and over-the-wire platform
Cutting Balloon® dilatation devices, the Maverick® XL Monorail™ balloon catheter and the Quantum™
Maverick® balloon catheter manufactured by Boston Scientific Corporation for the Department of Adult
Cardiology.
Reason:

Boston Scientific Corporation is the only known manufacturer and distributor of the LiberteTM
coronary artery stents, the Flextome™ Cutting Balloon® dilatation device, the Ultra2™
Monorail® and over-the-wire platfonn Cutting Balloon® dilatation devices, the Maverick®
XL Monorail™ balloon catheter and the Quantum™ Maverick® balloon catheter. These
coronary artery stents, Cutting Balloon® dilatation devices and balloon catheters are designed
for high risk patients with large-vessels that require stronger vessel support than the regular
size coronary angioplasty stents and catheters.

Estimated Fiscal Impact: $94,940.00 ($47 ,470.00 per year). Contract period: December 1, 2006 through
November 30, 2008. (897-362 Account). Requisition No. 78970015.
Approval of this item would commit Fiscal Year 2007 and future year funds.
The Office of the Purchasing Agent concurs with the recommendation.
Commissioner Daley, seconded by Commissioner Peraica, moved that the County Purchasing Agent be
authorized to enter into the requested contract. The motion carried unanimously.

The above referenced contract documents (and bonds, where required), have been executed by the
Contractors and approved as to form by the State's Attorney. Respectfully request that following
approval by your Honorable Body, the appropriate officials be authorized to sign same on behalf of the
County of Cook.
Copies of these executed documents will be available for inspection in the Office of the Purchasing Agent
and the Office of the Comptroller.
Commissioner Daley, seconded by Commissioner Silvestri, moved to ratify the action previously taken
with respect to the polled contracts and bonds, and authorizing the Proper Officials to sign on behalf of
Cook County. The motion carried.
Commissioner Collins voted "no".
Commissioner Hansen voted "no" on Contract No. 06-15-505H with Bioelectronic Engineering &
Medical Supplies (B.E.A.M.S.); Contract No. 05-15-266Hl with Dik Drug Company, Inc.; Contract
No. 06-15-505H with DMS Pharmaceutical Group, Inc.; Contract No. 06-15-505H with Ekla
Corporation; Contract No. 06-15-508H with Ekla Corporation; Contract No. 06-15-505H with

Supply Company; Contract No. 06-15-035H with Goodhealth Medical Products; Contract No. 0615-508H with Howard Medical Company; Contract No. 06-15-508H with MEDSED, LLC;
Contract No. 05-15-266Hl with MMS, A Medical Supply Company (Midwest Medical Supply
Company); Contract No. 06-15-505H with MMS, A Medical Supply Company (Midwest Medical
Supply Company); Contract No. 06-15-035H with Progressive Industries, Inc.; Contract No. 06-15266Hl with Progressive Industries, Inc.; Contract No. 06-15-505H with Progressive Industries,
Inc.; Contract No 06-15-508H with Progressive Industries, Inc.; and Contract No. 06-15-508H with
Trako Dental & Medical Supply, Inc.

269174

DOCKET #78 16 - JIMMY LIPKIN, Owner Application: 9754 South Torrence, Chicago,
Illinois 60617, Application (No. SU-05-01 ; Z050 I I). Submitted by same. The Special
Use for Unique Use, previously approved, was for a horse and gaming show and related
structures (barn, stable, etc.) in the R-3 Single Family Residence District in Section 3 I in
Bloom Township. Property consists of 4.76 acres located at the east side of Torrence
Avenue approximately 162 feet north of 30th Street in Bloom Township. Intended use:
Horse gaming show and related structures. Recommendation: That the application be
granted a one year extension of time.

Communication No. 269174. The motion carried.

SECTION 2
Your Committee has considered the following numbered and described applications requesting a public
hearing before the Cook County Zoning Board of Appeals on a request for a Special Use, Unique Use on
certain property described therein:

170

 JOURNAL OF PROCEEDINGS FOR SEPTEMBER 7, 2006

278215

DOCKETS #8097 & 8085 - KEVIN J. BRANNICK, Owner, 7900 West 39th Street,
Riverside, Illinois 60546, Application (No. SU-06-07; Z06092). Submitted by same.
Seeking a SPECIAL USE, UNIQUE USE in the R-5 Single Family Residence District for
rental of an existing coach house on an existing well and septic system and a Variation to
reduce distance between principal and accessory structure from IO' to 8' left side yard
setback (existing detached garage); reduce right comer side yard setback from 15' to 11 '
(existing residence); reduce right corner side yard setback from 15' to 4' (existing coach
house); reduce rear yard setback from 10' to 2' (existing coach house) and existing single
family residence, in Section 36 of Riverside Township. Property consists of 1/4 of an
acre, located on the northwest comer of West 39th Street and Stanley A venue in
Riverside Township. Intended use: Continued use as a one bedroom rental property as
has been the case for the last 60+ years. No improvements. All prior improvements have
been inspected and approved by the Cook County Department of Building Zoning.
Recommendation: That application be granted.

278216

DOCKET #8096 - GREGORY DANIELS, Owner, 15 N 365 Old Sutton Road,
Barrington Hills, Illinois 600 I0, Application (No. SU-06-06; Z06086). Submitted by
same. Seeking a SPECIAL USE, UNIQUE USE in the R-1 Single Family Residence
District to maintain the current tree nursery, landscaping business with employee living
quarters and snow plowing service, storage and sales in Section 28 of Barrington
Township. Property consists of 19.642 acres, located at the southeast intersection of
Elgin, Joliet and Eastern Railroad tracks and Sutton Road in Barrington Township.
Intended use: Amended application for tree nursery, landscaping business with employee
living quarters and snow plowing service, storage and sales. Recommendation: That the
application be granted.

The Cook County Zoning Board of Appeals to whom said applications were referred, submitted a
Communication setting forth its findings and recommendations following public hearings held thereon,
and recommended that the said application(s) be granted subject to conditions as stated in the findings.
Commissioner Moreno, seconded by Commissioner Goslin, moved the approval of Communication
Nos. 278215 and 278216. The motion carried.
06-0-32
ORDINANCE
AN ORDlNANCE GRANTING A SPECIAL USE
FOR UNIQUE USE LOCATED IN RIVERSIDE TOWNSHIP
AS AUTHORIZED BY THE COOK COUNTY ZONlNG ORDINANCE
WHEREAS, the owner of certain property located in Riverside Township described in Section I, herein,
has petitioned the Cook County Board of Commissioners for a Special Use for Unique Use pennit in the
R-5 Single Family Residence District; and
WHEREAS, the said petition was received by the Zoning Board of Appeals of Cook County as Docket
#8097 and #8085 and a public hearing was held in regard to said request after due notice, all in
accordance with the Cook County Zoning Ordinance and the Statutes of the State of Illinois; and
WHEREAS, the Zoning Board of Appeals entered detailed findings in accordance with the standards set
forth in the Ordinance recommending that the Cook County Board of Commissioners grant said
applications for a Special Use for Unique Use permit; and

171

 JOURNAL OF PROCEEDINGS FOR SEPTEMBER 7, 2006
WHEREAS, it is the determination that said request be granted in accordance with the recommendations
of the Zoning Board of Appeals.
NOW, THEREFORE, BE IT ORDAINED, by the Board of Commissioners of Cook County, Illinois:

Section 1:

That a Special Use for Unique Use for the rental of an existing coach house on existing
well and septic and a Variation to reduce distance between principal and accessory
structure from 10' to 8' (existing); reduce left side yard setback from 10' to 1.8' (existing
detached garage); reduce right comer side yard setback from 15' to 11' (existing
residence); reduce right comer side yard setback from 15' to 4' (existing coach house);
reduce rear yard setback from 10' to 2' (existing coach house) and existing single family
residence be granted.
LEGAL DESCRIPTION
Lots 1 l , 12 and 13 in Block 6, in Riverside Lawn, a subdivision of part of the Southwest
114 of Section 36, Township 39 North, Range 12, East of the 3rd Principal Meridian.

commonly described as approximately 0.25 acre, located on the Northwest comer of West 39th St. &
Stanley Ave. in Riverside Township.

Section 2:

That the Special Use for Unique Use located in the R-5 Single Family Residence District
as mentioned in Section 1 of this Ordinance is hereby authorized.

Section 3:

That this Ordinance under the provisions of Section 13.8.9 of the Cook County Zoning
Ordinance be in full force and effect from and after its passage and approval, except that
if said use is not established within one year as provided in Section 13.8. 14 said Special
Use for Unique Use shall be null and void. That said property be developed and
constructed pursuant to the detailing set forth in the testimony and contained in the
exhibits and Findings of the Cook County Zoning Board of Appeals hereby incorporated
by reference into this Ordinance, as provided by law.

Approved and adopted this 7th day of September 2006.
BOBBIE L. STEELE, President
Cook County Board of Commissioners
Attest: DA YID ORR, County Clerk

06-0-33
ORDINANCE
AN ORDINANCE GRANTING A SPECIAL USE
FOR UNIQUE USE LOCATED I N BARRINGTON TOWNSHIP
AS AUTHORIZED BY THE COOK COUNTY ZONING ORDINANCE
WHEREAS, the owner of certain property located in Barrington Township described in Section 1,
herein, has petitioned the Cook County Board of Commissioners for a Special Use for Unique Use permit
in the R-1 Single Family Residence District; and

172

 JOURNAL OF PROCEEDINGS FOR SEPTEMBER 7, 2006

WHEREAS, the said petition was received by the Zoning Board of Appeals of Cook County as Docket
#8096 and a public hearing was held in regard to said request after due notice, all in accordance with the
Cook County Zoning Ordinance and the Statutes of the State of Illinois; and
WHEREAS, the Zoning Board of Appeals entered detailed findings in accordance with the standards set
forth in the Ordinance recommending that the Cook County Board of Commissioners grant said
applications for a Special Use for Unique Use pennit; and
WHEREAS, it is the determination that said request be granted in accordance with the recommendations
of the Zoning Board of Appeals.
NOW, THEREFORE, BE IT ORDAINED, by the Board of Commissioners of Cook County, Illinois:
Section 1:

That a Special Use for Unique Use to maintain the current tree nursery, landscaping
business with employee living quarters and snow plowing service, storage and sales in
the R-1 Single Family Residence District be granted.

LEGAL DESCRIPTION
The West 1/2 of the Northeast 1/4 of the Southwest 1/4 of Section 28, Township 42
North, Range 9, East of the 3rd Principal Meridian.
commonly described as approximately 19.64 acres, located at the Southeast intersection of Elgin Joliet &
Eastern R.R. tracks & Sutton Rd. in Barrington Township.

Section 2:

That the Special Use for Unique Use located in the R-1 Single Family Residence District
as mentioned in Section 1 of this Ordinance is hereby authorized.

Section 3:

That this Ordinance under the provisions of Section 13.8.9 of the Cook County Zoning
Ordinance be in full force and effect from and after its passage and approval, except that
if said use is not established within one year as provided in Section 13.8.14 said Special
Use for Unique Use shall be null and void. That said property be developed and
constructed pursuant to the detailing set forth in the testimony and contained in the
exhibits and Findings of the Cook County Zoning Board of Appeals hereby incorporated
by reference into this Ordinance, as provided by law.

Approved and adopted this 7th day of September 2006.
BOBBIE L. STEELE, President
Cook County Board of Commissioners
Attest: DAYID ORR, County Clerk

SECTION 2

be, and upon the adoption of this report, approved and that the County Comptroller and County Treasurer
are authorized and directed to issue checks to said claimants in the amounts recommended.

SCHILD CONSULTING, INC., Barrington, Illinois, submitting invoice totaling $35, 110.00,

COMMISSIONER BUTLER, SECONDED BY COMMISSIONER PERAICA, MOVED TO
RATIFY THE ACTION PREVIOUSLY TAKEN WITH RESPECT TO THE POLLED ITEMS
INCLUDING DIVISIONS, AND APPROVE THE REMAINDER OF THE HEALTH
FACILITIES' BILLS AND CLAIMS. THE MOTION CARRIED.

SECTION 4
Your Committee has considered the following communications from State's Attorney, Richard A. Devine
with reference to the industrial claims hereinafter mentioned.
Your Committee, therefore, recommends that the County Comptroller and County Treasurer be, and by
the adoption of this report, authorized and directed to issue checks to the Industrial Commission to be
paid from the Workmen's Compensation Fund.
280409

THOMAS WILCOX, in the course of his employment as a Deputy Sheriff for the Sheriff's
Court Services Division sustained accidental injuries on October 22, 2002. The accident
occurred when the Petitioner caught his foot on an elevation in the carpeting and fell to the
floor, and as a result he injured his left knee (twisting of knee, lateral subluxation of patella,
moderate joint effusion). On May 15, 2006 the Arbitrator entered a decision awarding the
Petitioner the sum of $12,341.74. State's Attorney, Richard A. Devine, is submitting
Industrial Commission Decision of Arbitrator, Award No. 02-WC-56781 in the amount of
$12,341.74 and recommends its payment. (Finance Subcommittee July 11, 2006). Attorney:
Richard W. Baum, Law Firm of Baum, Ruffolo & Marzal, Ltd.

*This item was previously approved by poll on 7/28/2006.
COMMISSIONER HANSEN VOTED PRESENT, AND COMMISSIONER COLLINS
VOTED NO ON THE ABOVE ITEM.
280410

HAROLD REYNAUD, in the course of his employment as a Painter for the Department of
Facilities Management sustained accidental injuries on December 14, 2001. The accident
occurred when the Petitioner was struck by a motor vehicle while crossing the street at 26th
and California, and as a result he injured his left leg and head (multiple blunt trauma, scalp
lacerations with sutures, loss of #3 1 tooth, loss of consciousness, tom posterior cruciate
ligament, tom medial cruciate ligament and medial meniscus, surgery to repair tom posterior
cruciate ligament, medial cruciate ligament and medial meniscus). On March 4, 2004 the
Arbitrator entered a decision awarding the Petitioner the sum of $72,228.83. State's
Attorney, Richard A. Devine, is submitting Industrial Commission Decision of Arbitrator,
Award No. 02-WC-9561 in the amount of $72,228.83 and recommends its payment.
(Finance Subcommittee July 11, 2006). Attorney: Larry Mack, Law Finn of Steven G.
Pinto, Ltd.

Petition and Order Nos. 01-WC- l l 06, 02-WC-549 (aggravation of pre-existing) and 03-WC37587 (aggravation of pre-existing) in the amount of$5,000.00 and recommends its payment.
(Finance Subcommittee July 11, 2006). Attorney: Patrick J. Ryan, Law Finn of Cohn,
Lambert, Ryan, Schneider & Gray, Ltd.
COMMISSIONER HANSEN VOTED PRESENT ON THE ABOVE ITEM.

check to Dominick L. Lanzito, Assistant State' s Attorney, for transmittal.

281283

STATE ' S ATTORNEY, Richard A. Devine, submitting communication advising the County
to accept Proposed Settlement of $ 12, 184.00 for the release and settlement of suit regarding
Bridgett M. Neal-Warr, individually, and as mother and next friend of Terronn Neal. a minor,
and Susie Moore v. Michael Sheahan, Sheriff of Cook County, in his official capacity, and
Jason E. Wunsh, Case No. 05-M 1-303882. This matter arises from allegations of bodily
injuries as a result of an automobi le accident involving a Sheriff's employee in Chicago. The
matter has been settled for the sum of $12, 184.00, which is within the authority granted to
this office by the Finance Committee's Subcommittee on Litigation at its meeting of June 7,
2006. State's Attorney recommends payment of $12, 184.00, made payable in two (2)
separate checks as follows: the first check in the amount of $9,000.00, made payable to
Bridgett Neal-Warr, individually and on behalf of Terronn Neal, and her attorneys, Robert A.
Langendorf, P.C., Kopoulos & Lowe, Benjamin and Shapiro, Ltd., Hugh Medical
Association, and Dr. Bailan Jin; and the second check in the amount of $3, 184.00, made
payable to Susie Moore, Kopoulos & Lowe, Benjamin and Shapiro, Ltd., Hugh Medical
Association, and Dr. Bailan Jin. Please forward the checks to Lauren Klein, Assistant State's
Attorney, for transmittal.

recommends that the County Comptroller and County Treasurer be, and by the adoption of this report,

recommended to the claimants.

*On February 15, 2005, the Cook County Board awarded this contract to MHA Group. On March
29, 2006, MHA Group was notified that they were in breach of contract in that they failed to deliver
per the terms of the contract. On April 13, 2006, a notice of default was sent to MHA Group
allowing them an additional twenty-four (24) hours to cure the breach. They failed to deliver the
product. In that the Office of Contract Compliance has advised that the second low bidder, Praxair
Healthcare Services, Inc. was non-responsive to the MBE/WBE Ordinance and the next bidder
responding exceeds the competitive cost level for this service, it is respectfully requested that this
contract be canceled and rebid.

REPORT OF THE AUDIT COMMITTEE
August 2, 2006
The Honorable,
The Board of Commissioners of Cook County

ATTENDANCE
Present:

Chainnan Daley, Vice Chainnan Goslin, Commissioners Hansen and Quigley (4)
Ex-Officio Members: Laura A. Burman - Cook County Auditor; and Thomas J. Glaser
- Chief Financial Officer, Bureau of Finance (2)

Absent:

Commissioner Butler (1)

Also Present:

Commissioner Peraica ( 1); Patrick T. Driscoll, Jr. - Deputy State's Attorney, Chief,
Civil Actions Bureau; Kevin Burden - Chief Deputy Assessor, Cook County Assessor's
Office; John Morales - Chief Financial Officer, Clerk of the Circuit Court; and Walter
K. Knorr - Cook County Comptroller

Court Reporter: Anthony W. Lisanti, C.S.R.
Ladies and Gentlemen:
Your Audit Committee of the Board of Commissioners of Cook County met pursuant to notice on
Wednesday, August 2, 2006 at the hour of 11 :00 A.M. in the Board Room, Room 569, County Building,
11 8 North Clark Street, Chicago, Illinois.
Chairman Daley called the meeting of the Audit Committee to order, and noting that a quorum was
present, recessed the meeting to the call of the chair.
Chairman Daley called the recessed meeting of the Audit Committee to order, and stated that he is
submitting for the record copies of letters to the Clerk of the Circuit Court, Sheriff, and Treasurer,
requesting additional information regarding matters addressed by audits of their respective offices. (The
referenced documents are on file in the Office of the County Clerk.)

372

 JOURNAL OF PROCEEDINGS FOR SEPTEMBER 7, 2006

Your Committee has considered the following items and upon adoption of this report, the
recommendations are as follows:
278224

SHERIFF OF COOK COUNTY, Michael F. Sheahan, by Jack Kelly, Chief Financial
Officer, transmitting a Communication, dated March 3, 2006:
submitting the Independent Auditor's Report dated January 27, 2006, from Sam
Macalusco & Associates, Inc., Certified Public Accountants for the period ending
November 30, 2005. This audit report contains a Statement of Revenues Collected,
Expenditures Paid and Changes in Fund Balances for the Federal Equitable Sharing
Program and the State Equitable Sharing Program administered by the Cook County
Sheriffs Office.

*Referred to the Audit Committee on 07/12/06.
Commissioner Hansen, seconded by Vice Chairman Goslin, moved to receive and file
Communication No. 278224. The motion carried.
279317

CLERK OF THE CIRCUIT COURT, Dorothy Brown, transmitting a Communication,
dated May 25, 2006:
submitting the Fiscal Year 2005 Independent Auditor's Report and Memorandum on
Internal Controls for the Office of the Clerk of the Circuit Court. Please accept these
reports and refer them to the Audit Committee for the appropriate review.

*Referred to the Audit Committee on 04/18/06.
Commissioner Hansen asked what action is taken when a non-sufficient funds (NSF) check is received by
the Clerk of the Circuit Court.
John Morales, Chief Financial Officer, Clerk of the Circuit Court, stated that when a check is returned
NSF there is automatically a $25 returned check fee that is added to the original amount due.
Commissioner Hansen asked what is the number of checks the Office of the Clerk of the Circuit Court
receives and how many are NSF.
Mr. Morales stated that the office processes approximately one million checks annually, and out of that
4,283 checks were returned NSF last year.
Commissioner Hansen asked whether the NSF checks the Clerk receives are submitted by lawyers, or by
individual litigants themselves.
Mr. Morales responded that the majority of NSF checks are submitted by practicing attorneys.
Chairman Daley asked Mr. Morales to relate the Audit Committee's concerns regarding NSF checks to
Dorothy Brown, Clerk of the Circuit Court.
Commissioner Hansen requested that the Cook County Auditor work with Mr. Morales, and if
appropriate, the State's Attorney's Office, to seek better methods of collecting sums due from NSF
checks. Laura A. Burman, Cook County Auditor, stated that she will work with Mr. Morales on the issue
ofNSF checks.

373

 JOURNAL OF PROCEEDINGS FOR SEPTEMBER 7, 2006

Commissioner Hansen, seconded by Vice Chairman Goslin, moved to receive and file
Communication No. 279317. The motion carried.
280249

OFFICE OF THE COUNTY TREASURER, by Daniel R. Degnan, Chief Deputy
Treasurer, transmitting a Communication, dated June 6, 2006:
The Office of the County Treasurer is pleased to submit to the Cook County Board of
Commissioners the Independent Auditor's Report of the Financial Statement as of
November 30, 2004 and 2005 .

*Referred to the Audit Committee on 06/06/06.
Commissioner Hansen, seconded by Vice Chairman Goslin, moved to receive and file
Communication No. 280249. The motion carried.
INFORMATION ONLY
American Institute of Certified Public Accountants, Statement on Auditing Standards No. 99.

Commissioner Hansen, seconded by Vice Chairman Goslin, moved to receive and file the Statement
on Auditing Standards No. 99. The motion carried.
EXECUTIVE SESSION
A request was made to adjourn to executive session for the purpose of discussing a matter of pending
litigation. The request for a closed meeting was made pursuant to an exception to the Open Meetings Act,
5 ILCS 120/2(c)(l 1): " Litigation, when an action against, affecting, or on behalf of the particular public
body has been filed and is pending before a court or administrative tribunal, or when the public body
finds that an action is probable or imminent, in which case the basis for the finding shall be recorded and
entered into the minutes of the closed meeting."

Commissioner Hansen, seconded by Vice Chairman Goslin, moved to recess the regular meeting
and convene in Executive Session. The motion carried.
Commissioner Hansen, seconded by Vice Chairman Goslin, moved to return to Open Session. The
motion carried.
Chairman Daley noted for the record that the Executive Session was for discussion purposes only, and no
action was taken during that time.

Commissioner Hansen, seconded by Vice Chairman Goslin, moved to adjourn the meeting. The
motion carried and the meeting was adjourned.
Respectfully submitted,
AUDIT COMMITTEE
JOHN P. DALEY, Chairman
ATTEST: MICHELLE HARRIS, Secretary

374

 JOURNAL OF PROCEEDINGS FOR SEPTEMBER 7, 2006

The transcript for this meeting is available in the Office of the Secretary to the Board, 118 North Clark
Street, Room 567, Chicago, Illinois 60602.

Commissioner Daley, seconded by Commissioner Hansen, moved that the Report of the Audit Committee
be approved and adopted. The motion carried unanimously.

REPORT OF THE COMMITTEE ON CONTRACT COMPLIANCE

July 13, 2006
The Honorable,
The Board of Commissioners of Cook County
ATTENDANCE

Present:

Chairman Steele, Commissioners Maldonado, Moreno and Peraica (4)

Absent:

Vice Chairman Silvestri and Commissioners Goslin and Butler (3)

Also Present:

Commissioner Collins (I); Betty Hancock Perry - Contract Compliance Administrator,
Office of Contract Compliance; Colette Holt - Attorney at Law and MBE/WBE
Consultant; and Michael Prinzi - Division Chief, Transactions, Municipal Litigation &
Real Estate Taxation Division, States Attorney's Office

Ladies and Gentlemen:
Your Committee on Contract Compliance of the Board of Commissioners of Cook County met for
infonnational purposes only pursuant to notice on Thursday, July 13, 2006, at the hour of 10:00 A.M., in
the Board Room, Room 569, County Building, 11 8 North Clark Street, Chicago, Illinois.
Chairman Steele introduced Colette Holt, Attorney at Law and MBE/WBE Consultant. Chainnan Steele
stated that the original construction piece of the MBE/WBE Ordinance was deemed unconstitutional, and
that Ms. Holt has been working to restore constitutionality to this piece of the Ordinance.
At Chairman Steele' s request, the Secretary read the Notice into the record.
Ms. Holt delivered the following presentation concerning her report, which is entitled " Review of
Compelling Evidence of Discrimination against MBE/WBEs":
Race- and gender-conscious programs are subject to the highest level of judicial review, which is called
"strict constitutional scrutiny." The government agency bears the burden of proving that its programs are
constitutional. Racial goals cannot be calculated proportionate to the County's population. Economic
development is not seen as an adequate motive. Discrimination must be proven to be marketplace driven
or business driven, and not societal.

375

 JOURNAL OF PROCEEDINGS FOR SEPTEMBER 7, 2006
The following statistics must be compiled regarding MBE/WBEs: government utilization, availability,
disparities in the rate that regular and MBE/WBEs are fonned, and disparities regarding their experience
and access to capital. Anecdotal evidence seems to be increasingly accepted over the past several years,
however alone it does not suffice. Evidence must be shown regarding the current effects of past biases
and exclusions of the industries being studied.
A governmental program must be narrowly tailored. You must be able to prove that your program
implemented race-neutral measures. Your goals must have a solid relationship to the availability of
MBE/WBEs, and you must engage in contract-specific goal setting. Simply setting quotas will not work.
Your program must be flexible; you must be able to give waivers. If you don't, it's a quota. You must be
aware of the adverse impact on third parties; and make sure it is not too difficult to contract with the
agency. Finally, there must be some limit on the program, a regular review with a sunset date is critical.
Ms. Holt gave an overview of the cases that her report reviewed. She stated that this information would
be available as an appendix on disk to anyone who is interested.
Ms. Holt continued that in the report she reviewed the County ' s utilization of MBE/WBEs, breaking it
down into the period when the program was in effect (1993-2000) and the period since the injunction
(although the records for this period are limited). During the period of 1993 to 2000, the County had a
30% MBE and a I 0% WBE goal, and MBE/WBEs received approximately 25% of the professional
services prime consultant dollars and almost 24% of the prime construction dollars, and approximately
23% of the construction subcontractor dollars. Records are not available as to the sub-consultant
utilization.
Since the striking down of the Ordinance in 2000, the County, in compliance with the Court, has stopped
setting MBE/WBE goals; there have been drastic reductions on the construction side. However,
MBE/WBEs received 49% of the professional services prime consultant programs. MBE/WBEs received
approximately 17% of the construction contracts.
Ms. Holt continued by presenting the recommendations for an interim MBE/WBE Construction Program:
The County needs to conduct a disparity study. This study should include five years' worth of data, as
well as availability estimates, utilization analysis, disparity testing on both the County's own data and in
the private sector, and anecdotal evidence. Credit and business experience surveys should be done.
Race- and gender-neutral initiatives should be enacted. Enhanced prime contractor record keeping should
be encouraged. The County should un-bundle contracts where possible. Existing prompt payment
policies should be enforced. The County should review bonding and insurance requirements. It should
require that subcontractors receive prior approval before being substituted on the job. The County should
consider adopting: a financing and bonding program; a small business set-aside program; a mentorprotege program; a business assistance program; and a commercial non-discrimination complaint
procedure.
Regarding race- and gender-conscious remedies, Ms. Holt recommends that a personal-net-worth test and
size restrictions be required, and that the County move to contract-by-contract goal setting. There should
be a review of contract award procedures. There must be good faith efforts language in the special
conditions area of the bids document. Contracts must be monitored.
These recommendations will require additional funding. Also, the program must be integrated into the
overall County culture, not only the Contract Compliance Department, and specifically into other
departments that handle construction.

376

 JOURNAL OF PROCEEDINGS FOR SEPTEMBER 7, 2006

Ms Holt reiterated that there must be a sunset date to ensure the Courts that Cook County will continue to
gather evidence and fulfill its obligations to the Court.
Betty Hancock Perry, Contract Compliance Administrator, Office of Contract Compliance, provided the
following status report: Her Department has been working with the MIS Department and is about to
launch a test pilot to gather infonnation regarding disparity and availability among MBE/WBEs and nonminority vendors. They are waiting for Ms. Holt's approval of this test pilot. They have also worked
with the Purchasing Department and the Office of Capital Planning and Policy. They've begun to put
together a training program for the purchasing personnel of all County elected officials, including the
Assessors and Sheriff's Office. Her Department has also been working with the Procurement
Department.
Commissioner Maldonado inquired as to what the next step would be in order to achieve an interim
ordinance.
Ms. Holt stated that we could have a public hearing and then create an interim ordinance. Another option
is to simultaneously hold a public hearing and present an interim ordinance.
Commissioner Collins suggested that a resolution be passed to authorize and fund a disparity study.
Ms. Holt offered the following clarification that her report is not a substitute for a disparity study. She
recommends passing an ordinance while simultaneously conducting a disparity study within a certain
time frame and with a sunset date certain. The study will take approximately eighteen months. Ms. Holt
further stated that the County has been trying to launch a multijurisdictional disparity study, which would
save the County significant money.
Commissioner Maldonado inquired whether Chainnan Steele expects to introduce an ordinance at the
County Board meeting in September.
Chainnan Steele replied in the affirmative.
Chainnan Steele asked the Secretary to the Board to call upon the following registered public speakers.
I.
2.
3.

Chun Lin Leonhar - Partner, Sonnenschein, Nath & Rosenthal
Florence Ax - Executive Director, Black Contractors Union
George Blakemore - Concerned Citizen

Chairman Steele adjourned the meeting.
Respectfully submitted,
COMMITTEE ON CONTRACT COMPLIANCE
BOBBIE L. STEELE, Chairman
ATTEST: MICHELLE HARRIS, Secretary

Commissioner Butler, seconded by Commissioner Murphy, moved that the Report of the Committee on
Contract and Compliance be approved and adopted. The motion carried unanimously.

 JOURNAL OF PROCEEDINGS FOR SEPTEMBER 7, 2006

REPORT OF THE COMMITTEE ON HEALTH AND HOSPITALS
July 19, 2006
The Honorable,
The Board of Commissioners of Cook County

ATTENDANCE
Present:

Chainnan Butler, Vice Chairman Goslin, Commissioners Claypool, Collins, Daley,
Gorman, Hansen, Maldonado, Moreno, Murphy, Peraica, Quigley, Silvestri, Sims,
Steele and Suffredin ( 16)

Absent:

None (0)

Excused Absence: President Stroger (1)
Also Present:

Daniel H. Winship, M.D. - Chief, Bureau of Health Services; Helen Haynes and
Elizabeth Reidy - State's Attorney's Office; Charles Bracken - Managing Director,
ACS Healthcare Solutions; Catherine Maras O ' Leary - Chief Information Officer,
Bureau of Information Technology and Automation; and Robert Mills - National
Practice Leader for Public Hospitals

Ladies and Gentlemen:
Your Committee on Health and Hospitals of the Board of Commissioners of Cook County met pursuant
to notice on Wednesday, July 19, 2006, at the hour of 1:30 P.M. in the Board Room, Room 569, County
Building, 11 8 North Clark Street, Chicago, Illinois.
Chairman Butler stated that Dr. Daniel Winship, Chief, Bureau of Health Services, will make a
presentation regarding the contract with ACS Healthcare Solutions.
Dr. Winship began by acknowledging the members on the team that worked on the project.
Dr. Winship stated that at the Board Meeting of July 12, 2006, the Bureau of Health Services presented a
request for a proposal process, and through the process the Bureau of Health Services had a proposal that
they wish for the Purchasing Agent to enter into a contract with ACS Healthcare Solutions. The process
by which the Bureau of Health Services came to this conclusion and to this point was lengthy. Dr.
Winship continued by explaining the proposal process to the Committee.
Your Committee has considered the following item and upon adoption of this report, the recommendation
is as follows:
280247

BUREAU OF HEALTH SERVICES, by Daniel H. Winship, M.D., Chief and by
Catherine Maras O' Leary, Chief lnfonnation Officer, BUREAU OF INFORMATION
TECHNOLOGY AND AUTOMATION, transmitting a Communication:
requesting authorization for the Purchasing Agent to enter into a contract with ACS
Healthcare Solutions, Dearborn, Michigan, for information technology (IT) services for
the Bureau of Health Services (BHS).

378

 JOURNAL OF PROCEEDINGS FOR SEPTEMBER 7, 2006

Reason:

Through a request for proposal process ACS Healthcare Solutions had the
lowest cost proposal and met all County requirements. This proposed
contract will provide staff augmentation services to meet the technology
needs of the data center, help desktop, application support, network, and
packaged rollout and application development (PRAD) towers and improve
the IT service delivery model through standardization, the creation of service
level agreements and better coordination with the County's Bureau of
Infonnation Technology and Automation. Moreover, the base cost of this
proposal minus the additional monies included for PRAD services is
approximately 42 percent lower than the current provider. ACS will
complete the installation of BHS-owned applications, including the Cemer
system, and will supplement the staff that is currently identified in this
proposal at peak times at no additional cost to the County. For the revenue
cycle, ACS will assess and remedy any issues relating to the Cemer/Siemens
interface as an additional commitment to the County. Accordingly, ACS has
met the County's MBE/WBE requirement.

$4,807, 122.00; Year 2:
Estimated Fiscal Impact:
$ 14,607, 122.00 (Year 1:
$4,850,000.00; and Year 3: $4,950,000.00). Contract period: January 1, 2007 through
December 31, ~ 2009. (897-260 Account). Requisition No. 78970014.
Approval of this item would commit Fiscal Year 2007 and future year funds.

*Referred to the Health and Hospitals Committee on 07/12/06.
Commissioner Maldonado asked if a background check was performed on semi-finalist companies.
Dr. Winship stated that the Bureau of Health Services contacted a number of the organizations that the
Bureau knew had done previous work in the past and received satisfactory comments about the
companies.
Commissioner Maldonado asked Dr. Winship if he was familiar with the "Triangle Business Journal" , a
business publication from No11h Carolina.
Dr. Winship responded that he was not familiar with the " Triangle Business Journal ," but he suggested
that maybe someone from ACS Healthcare Solutions might be familiar with the publication.
Charles Bracken, Managing Director, ACS Healthcare Solutions, responded that he is fa miliar with the
contract that Commissioner Maldonado is speaking to and that it is not part of his division. Mr. Bracken
stated that it is not part of the business that he runs; his business focuses exclusively on assisting hospitals
and health systems. Further, Mr. Bracken stated that ACS Healthcare Solutions has 55,000 employees
and that there are other parts of the business that focus on that type of work with state government.
Commissioner Maldonado stated that due to the fact that ACS Healthcare Solutions was unable to
respond to his question, at the appropriate time he will move to defer action on this contract until the
Committee receives an answer from ACS Healthcare Solutions so as to hear what happened in North
Carolina.
Dr. Winship stated that this particular organization of ACS Healthcare Solutions was not the healthcare
hospitals healthcare organization, and that is where the Bureau of Health Services has focused their
attention.

379

 JOURNAL OF PROCEEDINGS FOR SEPTEMBER 7, 2006

Commissioner Collins stated that she shared the same concerns as Commissioner Maldonado.
Commissioner Collins inquired whether ACS Healthcare Solutions is a minority-owned company.
Dr. Winship responded that it was not a minority-owned company.
Commissioner Peraica asked if ACS Healthcare Solutions can guarantee no-cost overruns and that they
will not come to the County Board for an additional appropriation other than what is indicated in the
contract.
Mr. Bracken stated that ACS Healthcare Solutions can do the work as requested and as scoped by the
County's RFP for the prices and the commitments that were made in their response.
Commissioner Peraica inquired whether ACS Healthcare Solutions will retain all of the currently
employed Foster Group personnel as part of their team that will go through the transi tion if the agreement
is approved through the end of 2006 and beyond.
Mr. Bracken responded that ACS Healthcare Solutions will attempt to retain as many individuals as
possible.
Commissioner Peraica asked if the County's staff or the current vendor take longer than anticipated,
would that increase the cost.
Mr. Bracken stated that the cost could not be increased unless it was legally agreed and contracted to
increase it.
Commissioner Daley requested that the Commissioners receive clarification before this contract ts
approved at the September 7, 2006 Board Meeting as to whether it is in litigation.
Commissioner Claypool asked what strategy ACS Healthcare Solutions will use for achieving the 41 %
savings.
Mr. Bracken stated that ACS Healthcare Solutions looked at the commitment based on the RFP, the staff
that needs to be put in place, the cost of maintaining the staff and additional training for some of the
employees that would remain and a fair profit; and that is how ACS Healthcare Solutions arrived at that
number.

Commissioner Daley, seconded by Commissioner Gorman, moved approval of Communication No.
280247, as amended. Commissioner Claypool called for a Roll Call, the vote of yeas and nays being
as follows:

RESOLUTIONS
06-R-330
RESOLUTION

Sponsored by
THE HONORABLE BOBBIE L. STEELE
PRESIDENT OF THE BOARD OF COMMISSIONERS
WHEREAS, on Saturday, September 9, 2006 at 7:00 a.m. Cook County will be participating in the 23rd
Annual United Negro College Fund Walk-Run-Bike-Skate-A-Thon in Grant Park at Hutchinson Field,
Columbus Drive and Balbo; and
WHEREAS, the United Negro College Fund (UNCF) is an educational assistance organization wi th 39
private, Historically Black member colleges and universities; and
WHEREAS, its mission is to enhance the quality of education by providing financial assistance to
deserving students, raising operating funds, providing program services, and offering technical assistance
to support its member colleges and their students; and
WHEREAS, since its inception, the College Fund has raised more than 2.3 billion dollars for historically
black colleges and universities and their students; and
WHEREAS, the College Fund offers more than 400 programs for students, faculty, and member
colleges. These program services range from scholarships and curriculum development to college
preparation and faculty development; and
WHEREAS, more than 65,000 students currently attend UNCF member colleges. Approximately 90%
require financial assistance; 40% are the first in their fami lies to attend college; and 34% are from
families with a gross income of less than $25,000.00; and

38 1

 JOURNAL OF PROCEEDINGS FOR SEPTEMBER 7, 2006

WHEREAS, to date more than 350,000 men and women have graduated from UNCF colleges.
Historically Black colleges and universities have graduated 75% of black PhD's, 85% of black doctors,
46% of black business executives, 50% of black attorneys, and 75% of black military officers; and
WHEREAS, your gift will help UNCF colleges continue to provide quality education at an affordable
cost.
NOW, THEREFORE, BE IT RESOLVED, that the Board of Commissioners congratulates and
supports the efforts of the United Negro College Fund; and
BE IT FURTHER RESOLVED, that this text be spread upon the official proceedings of this Honorable
Body, and a suitable copy of same be tendered to the Midwestern Area Headquarters of the United Negro
College Fund.
Approved and adopted this 7th day of September 2006.
BOBBIE L. STEELE, President
Cook County Board of Commissioners
Attest: DAYID ORR, County Clerk

Commissioner Sims, seconded by Commissioner Moreno, moved that the Resolution be approved and
adopted. T he motion carried unanimously.

06-R-331
RESOLUTION
Sponsored by
THE HONORABLE ANTHONY J. PERAi CA, COUNTY COMMISSIONER
Co-Sponsored by
THE HONORABLE BOBBIE L. STEELE, PRESIDENT, JERRY BUTLER,
FORREST CLAYPOOL, EARLEAN COLLINS, JOHN P. DALEY,
ELIZABETH ANN DOODY GORMAN, GREGG GOSLIN, CARL R. HANSEN,
ROB ERTO MALDONADO, JOSEPH MARIO MORENO, JOAN PATRICIA MURPHY,
MIKE QUIGLEY, PETER N. SILVESTRI, DEBORAH SIMS AND LARRY SUFFREDIN
COUNTY COMMISSIONERS
FEDERAL FUNDING FOR VETERANS
WHEREAS, George Washington said, "The willingness with which our young people are likely to serve
in any war, no matter how justified, shall be directly proportionate to how they perceive the veterans of
earlier wars were treated and appreciated by their country"; and
WHEREAS, President Lincoln said, in a letter on December 2, 1863 [to George Opdyke and others],
"Honor to the Soldier, and Sai lor everywhere, who bravely bears his country's cause"; and

382

 JOURNAL OF PROCEEDINGS FOR SEPTEMBER 7, 2006

WHEREAS, Brigadier General Casi mir Pulaski said, " I came here, where freedom is being defended, to
serve, and to live or die for it"; and
WHEREAS, when the United States military has been called upon to send forces into hanns way, the
sons and daughters of our great County of Cook, in the State of Illinois, have answered the call. These
brave men and women enlisted to serve our country, as citizens of the United States agreed to provide
benefits; and
WHEREAS, the legislative bodies of government at all levels have recognized the importance of
supporting those who serve, however, the funding mechanisms for veterans are beset by numerous flaws
preventing many veterans from receiving the financial support they deserve; and
WHEREAS, there should be mandatory fully-funded and equal benefits for all United States unifonned
military, past, present and future; and
WHEREAS, our history has demonstrated that many of the debilitating health effects of military
conflicts, such as, post-traumatic stress syndrome, the consequences of exposure to agent orange during
the Vietnam War, the mysterious effects on veterans associated with the Gulf War may take years to
manifest themselves or remain undetected, although clearly connected to military service. Additionally,
these health problems may manifest themselves after the current limit of eligibility for related heal thcare
clai ms has expired; and
WHEREAS, these veterans, our heroes, have maintained their part of the bargain and now, we the people
need to uphold ours; and
WHEREAS, the United States House of Representative and Senate must ensure that these obligations to
our veterans reach the level of deserving healthcare funding that has been earned and promised for service
to our great country, and as such, be the example of governments on this front.
NOW, THEREFORE, BE IT RESOLVED, that the Cook County Board of Commissioners, on behalf
of all c itizens of the County of Cook, urge the United States House of Representative and Senate to
increase the funding of veterans' benefits to the levels necessary to meet our moral obligation for the
brave men and women of the United States military, past, present and future; and
BE IT FURTHER RESOLVED , that a suitable copy of this Resolution be prepared and presented to the
President of the Uni ted States and to members of the United States Congress.
Approved and adopted this 7th day of September 2006.
BOBBIE L. STEELE, President
Cook County Board of Commissioners
Attest: DA YID ORR, County Clerk

Commissioner Peraica, seconded by Commissioner Daley, moved that the Resolution be approved and
adopted. The motion carried unanimously.

383

 JOURNAL OF PROCEEDINGS FOR SEPTEMBER 7, 2006

06-R-336
RESOLUTION
Sponsored by
THE HONORABLE ELIZABETH ANN DOODY GORMAN, COUNTY COMMISSIONER
Co-Sponsored by
THE HONORABLE BOBBIE L. STEELE, PRESIDENT, JERRY BUTLER,
FORREST CLAYPOOL, EARLEAN COLLINS, JOHN P. DALEY, GREGG GOSLIN,
CARL R. HANSEN, ROBERTO MALDONADO, JOSEPH MARIO MORENO,
JOAN PATRICIA MURPHY, ANTHONY J. PERAICA, MIKE QUIGLEY,
PETER N. SILVESTRI, DEBORAH SIMS AND LARRY SUFFREDIN
COUNTY COMMISSIONERS

389

 JOURNAL OF PROCEEDINGS FOR SEPTEMBER 7, 2006

WHEREAS, on September 8th, 2000, Robert and Sandy Waters were blessed with their first child, a
beautiful baby girl which they named Candace; and

WHEREAS, at the age of three, Candace Waters was diagnosed with Autism, a neuro/biological brain
disorder that effects a child's ability to communicate; and

WHEREAS, after Candace was diagnosed, Mr. Waters, a musician and song writer, could not write, but
would play his guitar to daughter Candace, unable to bring himself to write a song; and

WHEREAS, Robert and Sandy Waters received a letter asking for donations in the name of Autism
research last Christmas with the message reminding them "They must have faith, love and hope"; and

WHEREAS, those words deeply touched Robert and Sandy, and that message gave them the inspiration
to raise greater awareness for Autism; and

WHEREAS, one evening as their five year old daughter Candace slept, Robert and Sandy spent the night
kicking around words that would end up as song lyrics; and

WHEREAS, that evening, by their inspiration Robert and Sandy Waters wrote their song titled "Faith,
Love and Hope'', which has now reached many ears across our country and abroad, to raise the awareness
and compassion of Autism.

NOW, THEREFORE, BE IT RESOLVED, that the Cook County Board of Commissioners express
their gratitude to Robert and Sandy Waters for their contribution to the awareness of Autism; and

BE IT FURTHER RESOLVED, that the text of this Resolution be spread across the official text of the
Journal of Proceedings of this Honorable Body and that a suitable copy hereof be tendered to Robert and
Sandy Waters and family.
Approved and adopted this 7th day of September 2006.
BOBBIE L. STEELE, President
Cook County Board of Commissioners
Attest: DAYID ORR, County Clerk

Commissioner Silvestri, seconded by Commissioner Quigley, moved that the Resolution be approved and
adopted. The motion carried unanimously.

390

 JOURNAL OF PROCEEDINGS FOR SEPTEMBER 7, 2006

* * * * *
06-R-337
RESOLUTION
Sponsored by
THE HONORABLE ANTHONY J. PERAICA, COUNTY COMMISSIONER
Co-Sponsored by
THE HONORABLE BOBBIE L. STEELE, PRESIDENT, JERRY BUTLER,
FORREST CLAYPOOL, EARLEAN COLLINS, JOHN P. DALEY,
ELIZABETH ANN DOODY GORMAN, GREGG GOSLIN, CARL R. HANSEN,
ROBERTO MALDONADO, JOSEPH MARIO MORENO, JOAN PATRICIA MURPHY,
MIKE QUIGLEY, PETER N. SILVESTRI, DEBORAH SIMS AND LARRY SUFFREDIN
COUNTY COMMISSIONERS
HONORING HELENA, ARKANSAS AND THE SONNY BOY BLUES SOCIETY
WHEREAS, the King Biscuit Time radio program began in Helena, Arkansas in 1941; and
WHEREAS, King Biscuit Time made history because it was the first radio program in the nation to
target African-Americans as an audience and regularly feature live blues music performed by AfricanAmericans; and
WHEREAS, King Biscuit Time, hosted by "Sunshine" Sonny Payne since 1942, is the longest running
daily live blues radio show in the U.S., which aired its fifteen-thousandth broadcast on KFFA in 2006;
and
WHEREAS, King Biscuit Time popularized blues music and influenced many legendary blues artists;
and
WHEREAS, the immense popularity of King Biscuit Time inspired several groups to make use of the
King Biscuit name, such as the King Biscuit Flower Hour, which began as a weekly syndicated radio
show in New York City in 1973; and
WHEREAS, the King Biscuit Blues Festival was launched in Helena, Arkansas in 1986 to preserve the
blues traditions of the Delta; and
WHEREAS, the Sonny Boy Blues Society, a non-profit group, fonned a free music festival that featured
perfonners from King Biscuit Time and those who were inspired by the perfonnances they heard on King
Biscuit Time; and
WHEREAS, this festival, originally named the King Biscuit Blues Festival, is now known as the
Arkansas Blues and Heritage Fest.
NOW, THEREFORE, BE IT RESOLVED, that the President and Board of Commissioners of Cook
County, Illinois does hereby recognize Helena, Arkansas and the Sonny Boy Blues Society as the original
creators of the King Biscuit Blues Fest name; and

391

 JOURNAL OF PROCEEDINGS FOR SEPTEMBER 7, 2006

BE IT FURTHER RESOLVED, that the President and Board of Commissioners recognizes HelenaWest Helena, Arkansas as a " Brother in the Blues" since many of Chicago's most prolific blues artists
and former Cook County Board President John H. Stroger, Jr. came to Chicago by way of Helena,
Arkansas.

Approved and adopted this 7th day of September 2006.
BOBBIE L. STEELE, President
Cook County Board of Commissioners
Attest: DAVID ORR, County Clerk

Commissioner Silvestri, seconded by Commissioner Quigley, moved that the Resolution be approved and
adopted. The motion carried unanimously.

COMMEMORATING THE FIFTH ANNIVERSARY OF THE TERRORIST ATTACKS
ON THE UNITED STATES ON 9/11/2001
WHEREAS, nearly three thousand lives were claimed by the terrorist attacks on the United States on
September 11, 2001; and
WHEREAS, these attacks were perpetrated by treacherous cowards who are intolerant of those who
differ from them and do not share their ideology; and
WHEREAS, America was founded on principles of democracy, individual freedom and tolerance; and
WHEREAS, Americans rallied together and sacrificed resources, and donated money, blood and
resources to various 9/ 11 rescue efforts and charities; and
WHEREAS, the ultimate sacrifice was made by 60 brave police officers, and 343 courageous paramedics
and firefighters ; and

392

 JOURNAL OF PROCEEDINGS FOR SEPTEMBER 7, 2006

WHEREAS, September 11 , 2006 marks the fifth anniversary of the brutal and senseless attacks on the
United States.
NOW, THEREFORE, BE IT RESOLVED, that the President and Board of Commissioners of Cook
County, Illinois does hereby recognize the fifth anniversary of the horrific events of September 11, 2001
and once again extend our heartfelt sympathies to the families of those who perished as a result of the
attacks on the United States, and urge all Americans to remember those who sacrificed and lost their lives
as a result of the September 11th attacks; and
BE IT FURTHER RESOLVED, that the President and Board of Commissioners recognize that we as
citizens, owe a debt of gratitude to the fearless men and women who perished on September 11, 200 I and
those police officers, firefighters, paramedics and members of the U.S. anned forces who are willing to
risk their safety and their lives to make our world a safer place to live and protect the American way of
life; and
BE IT FURTHER RESOLVED, that the President and Board of Commissioners celebrate the spirit that
makes America great and give thanks to God for the freedom we too often take for granted.
Approved and adopted this 7th day of September 2006.
BOBBIE L. STEELE, President
Cook County Board of Commissioners
Attest: DAVID ORR, County Clerk

Commissioner Silvestri, seconded by Commissioner Quigley, moved that the Resolution be approved and
adopted. The motion carried unanimously.

RESOLUTION
Sponsored by
THE HONORABLE ANTHONY J. PERAICA, COUNTY COMMISSIONER
Co-Sponsored by
THE HONORABLE BOBBIE L. STEELE, PRESIDENT, JERRY BUTLER,
FORREST CLAYPOOL, EARLEAN COLLINS, JOHN P. DALEY,
ELIZABETH ANN DOODY GORMAN, GREGG GOSLIN, CARL R. HANSEN,
ROBERTO MALDONADO, JOSEPH MARIO MORENO, JOAN PATRICIA MURPHY,
MIKE QUIGLEY, PETER N. SILVESTRI, DEBORAH SIMS AND LARRY SUFFREDIN
COUNTY COMMISSIONERS
RESOLUTION CELEBRATING NATIONAL HISPANIC HERITAGE MONTH

393

 JOURNAL OF PROCEEDINGS FOR SEPTEMBER 7, 2006

WHEREAS, National Hispanic Heritage Month is a celebration of Hispanic pride and culture, which
honors the contributions and accomplishments of Hispanic individuals who have distinguished
themselves by their passion, dedication and hard work; and
WHEREAS, the United States Congress approved Public Law 90-498 on September 17, 1968, which
recognized the week containing the 15th and 16th of September as National Hispanic Heritage Week; and
WHEREAS, Congress expanded this to the 31-day period between September 15 and October 15 under
Public Law 100-402 and changed the name to National Hispanic Heritage Month in 1988; and
WHEREAS, a group of Mexican freedom fighters began the fight for independence from Spain on
August 16, 1810 under the leadership of Father Miguel Hidalgo y Costilla; and
WHEREAS, Father Hidalgo was captured and executed by Spain for leading the revolt; and
WHEREAS, Mexicans worldwide celebrate Hidalgo' s declaration each year on the evening of
September 15th, by shouting " Mexicanos, Viva Mexico"; and
WHEREAS, Hidalgo and others who fought and died for Mexico's freedom have been an inspiration to
the worldwide Mexican community; and
WHEREAS, the vast majority of the Hispanic population in Cook County is of Mexican descent; and
WHEREAS, the Mexican-American community has made innumerable positive contributions to the
growth and development of Cook County.
NOW, THEREFORE, BE IT RESOLVED, that the President and Board of Commissioners of Cook
County, Illinois does hereby celebrate National Hispanic Heritage Month 2006, and proclaim September
16, 2006 to be Mexican Independence Day in Cook County; and
BE IT FURTHER RESOLVED, that the entire membership of the board encourages everyone to
celebrate the heritage and culture of the Mexican community; and
BE IT FURTHER RESOLVED, that this text be spread upon the official proceedings of this Honorable
Body.

Approved and adopted this 7th day of September 2006.
BOBBIE L. STEELE, President
Cook County Board of Commissioners
Attest: DAYID ORR, County Clerk

Commissioner Silvestri, seconded by Commissioner Quigley, moved that the Resolution be approved and
adopted. The motion carried unanimously.

 JOURNAL OF PROCEEDINGS FOR SEPTEMBER 7, 2006

Highlands, Illinois; and

and

leadership and practical skills to tomorrow's leaders; and
WHEREAS, Mr. Scheppler began his 12-year involvement with the Boy Scouts when he joined Cub
Scout Pack 216, and later joined Boy Scout Troop 216; and

where he served as Assistant Archery Instructor.

HONORING THE LIFE AND THE MEMORY OF ROBERT F. PECK, ATTORNEY AT LAW
WHEREAS, Almighty God in His Infinite wisdom has called Robert Peck from our midst; and
WHEREAS, Robert Peck was a loving and devoted husband to Carolyn Peck, who he married on June
19, 1965; and
WHEREAS, Robert Peck was admitted to the Jllinois Bar in 1964, and was also a member of the U.S.
Supreme Court Bar, Federal District Court of the Northern District of Illinois Bar, and the Arizona,
Indiana and Florida state bars; and
WHEREAS, Robert Peck had a great love and passion for the law that stayed with him throughout his
life; and
WHEREAS, this love of law was passed along to his son, Erik Peck, and his daughter, Michael-Anne
Peck, both of whom are attorneys; and
WHEREAS, Robert Peck was known as " Popeye" to his five grandchildren, whom he referred to
affectionately as "Sweet Pea'', "BaBa'', "Bruiser", "Inky", and "Abercrombie"; and
WHEREAS, Robert Peck believed deeply in public service, and was active m many community
organizations, including the Republican Organization of Lyons Township.
NOW, THEREFORE, BE IT RESOLVED, that the President and Board of Commissioners of Cook
County, Illinois do hereby extend their deepest condolences and most heartfelt sympathy to the family
and many friends of Robert Peck, and give thanks to God for the life and memory of Robert Peck; and

396

 JOURNAL OF PROCEEDINGS FOR SEPTEMBER 7, 2006

BE IT FURTHER RESOLVED, that this text be spread upon the official proceedings of this Honorable
Body, and a suitable copy of same be tendered to the family of Robert Peck, that his memory may be so
honored and ever cherished.

COUNTY COMMISSIONERS
CELEBRATING THE 14TH ANNIVERSARY OF THE HAMDARD CENTER
WHEREAS, the Hamdard Center for Health and Human Services, a not-for profit community institution,
was established by a group of dedicated community activists with broad based community support in
1992;and
WHEREAS, the Hamdard Center is dedicated to servmg the South Asian, Middle Eastern, and
mainstream communities in Illinois; and
WHEREAS, the Hamdard Center owns and operates its own fully functional shelter facility; and
WHEREAS, the Hamdard Center has its own licensed Family Violence Intervention Program based on
the internationally recognized Duluth Domestic Intervention Project Model; and
WHEREAS, the Hamdard Center is now a comprehensive behavioral and mental health agency that
provides an array of clinically focused services; and

397

 JOURNAL OF PROCEEDINGS FOR SEPTEMBER 7, 2006

WHEREAS, the Hamdard Center is a licensed Child Welfare Agency that can recruit, train, and license
foster parents; and
WHEREAS, the Hamdard Center has its own transitional housing programs for its shelter residents; and
WHEREAS, the Hamdard Center has for many years been a recognized training and internship site for
doctoral and masters level psych and counseling interns from several major academic institutions in the
Chicago area; and
WHEREAS, 2006 marks the 14th year of operation for the Hamdard Center.
NOW, THEREFORE, BE IT RESOLVED, that the President and Board of Commissioners of Cook
County, Illinois do hereby extend their congratulations and gratitude to the Hamdard Center for 14 years
of excellence in public service; and
BE IT FURTHER RESOLVED, that a suitable copy of this Resolution be presented to Dr. Mohammad
Hamid, who serves as Chairman of the Board at the Hamdard Center, in honor of this achievement.
Approved and adopted this 7th day of September 2006.
BOBBIE L. STEELE, President
Cook County Board of Commissioners
Attest: DAVID ORR, County Clerk

Commissioner Silvestri, seconded by Commissioner Quigley, moved that the Resolution be approved and
adopted. The motion carried unanimously.

06-R-343
RESOLUTION
Sponsored by

THE HONORABLE LARRY SUFFREDIN, COUNTY COMMISSIONER
Co-Sponsored by

THE HONORABLE BOBBIE L. STEELE, PRESIDENT, JERRY BUTLER,
FORREST CLAYPOOL, EARLEAN COLLINS, JOHN P. DALEY,
ELIZABETH ANN DOODY GORMAN, GREGG GOSLIN, CARL R. HANSEN,
ROBERTO MALDONADO, JOSEPH MARIO MORENO, JOAN PA TRICIA MURPHY,
ANTHONY J. PERAICA, MIKE QUIGLEY, PETER N. SILVESTRI AND DEBORAH SIMS
COUNTY COMMISSIONERS
IN MEMORY OF MARY JEANNE "DOLLY" HALLSTROM
WHEREAS, Mary Jeanne " Dolly" Hallstrom was a lifelong advocate for people with disabilities; and

398

 JOURNAL OF PROCEEDINGS FOR SEPTEMBER 7, 2006

WHEREAS, Dolly Hallstrom passed away at the age of 81 on August 2, 2006; and
WHEREAS, Dolly Hallstrom was born in East Orange, New Jersey, came to Evanston, where she met
her future husband, Gordon, who gave her the nickname, "Dolly," and began to study nursing at Loyola
University; and
WHEREAS, Dolly Hallstrom dedicated her entire life to raising awareness about the challenges faced by
people with disabilities and improving their quality of life, beginning when, in 1955 as a member of the
North Shore Junior Women's Club, she spearheaded a fundraiser that raised $5,000 for the education of a
child with disabilities; and
WHEREAS, Dolly Hallstrom continued her success by organizing what is believed to be the first
national meeting of educators, medical experts and parents to discuss the educational needs of impaired
and learning-disabled youngsters; and
WHEREAS, Dolly Hallstrom founded the Fund for Perceptually Handicapped Children and served as
president from 1957 to 1963 and co-founded the National Association of Children with Learning
Disabilities; and
WHEREAS, Dolly Hallstrom served as a volunteer lobbyist on behalf of parents of children with
learning disabilities and played an important role in the passage of legislation to mandate special
education in public schools; and
WHEREAS, from 1968 to 1970 Dolly Hallstrom served as Illinois chairperson of the White House
Conference Commission on Mental Health and Developmental Disabilities and from 1975 to 1977 she
worked with the Illinois State Board of Education on behalf of children with disabilities; and
WHEREAS, shortly after the death of her husband in 1977, and when running for the Illinois House of
Representatives, Dolly Hallstrom suffered a stroke that left her paralyzed on her left side, yet she stayed
in the race and won election; and
WHEREAS, Dolly Hallstrom continued her remarkable career of success in Springfield as a legislator
from 1978 to 1982, helping to pass the Illinois Human Rights Act to protect people from discrimination
based on age, sex, race or disabilities and became one of the founders of the Conference of Women
Legislators (COWL); and
WHEREAS, upon retirement from the General Assembly after two tenns, Dolly Hallstrom was
legislative resource coordinator for Equip for Equality, and later became a board member; and
WHEREAS, in 1991 , Dolly Hallstrom was appointed by Governor Jim Edgar to the Illinois Human
Rights Commission, where she served until her death; and
WHEREAS, Dolly Hallstrom is survived by her son Gordon Hallstrom, daughter Amy Bejarano and
grandson Etienne Bejarano; and
WHEREAS, Dolly Hallstrom will be deeply missed and forever treasured by all who knew her and the
people of Cook County owe a debt of gratitude to Dolly Hallstrom for her extensive community service
and outstanding civic involvement.

399

 JOURNAL OF PROCEEDINGS FOR SEPTEMBER 7, 2006

NOW, THEREFORE, BE IT RESOLVED, that the Board of Commissioners of Cook County does
hereby offer its deepest condolences and most heartfelt sympathy to the family and friends of Dolly
Hallstrom and joins them in sorrow at this time of loss; and
BE IT FURTHER RESOLVED, that a suitable copy of this Resolution be spread upon the official
proceedings of this Honorable Body and that an official copy of same be tendered to the family of Dolly
Hallstrom so that her memory may be so honored and ever cherished.
Approved and adopted this 7th day of September 2006.
BOBBIE L. STEELE, President
Cook County Board of Commissioners
Attest: DAVID ORR, County Clerk

Commissioner Silvestri, seconded by Commissioner Quigley, moved that the Resolution be approved and
adopted. The motion carried unanimously.

* * ** *
06-R-344
RESOLUTION
Sponsored by
THE HONORABLE LARRY SUFFREDIN, COUNTY COMMISSIONER
Co-Sponsored by
THE HONORABLE BOBBIE L. STEELE, PRESIDENT, JERRY BUTLER,
FORREST CLAYPOOL, EARLEAN COLLINS, JOHN P. DALEY,
ELIZABETH ANN DOODY GORMAN, GREGG GOSLIN, CARL R. HANSEN,

ANTHONY J. PERAICA, MIKE QUIGLEY, PETER N. SILVESTRI AND DEBORAH SIMS
COUNTY COMMISSIONERS
IN MEMORY O F HERBERT B. AND MARY A. BAIN
WHEREAS, Herbert and Mary Bain were tireless leaders in the community whose dedication to the
improvement of civic life deserve to be praised; and
WHEREAS, Herbert Bain died on June 11 , 2006 and Mary Bain died on August 7, 2006; and
WHEREAS, in 1911 , Herbert Bain was born in Rochelle and Mary Bain was born in De Kalb; and
WHEREAS, after graduating from the University of Chicago, Herbert Bain began to work as a reporter
for the Rociford Morning Star and moved to the Chicago Herald-American in 1939; and

400

 JOURNAL OF PROCEEDINGS FOR SEPTEMBER 7, 2006

WHEREAS, after becoming active in local Democratic politics, Mary Bain worked in the Roosevelt
Administration as an original "New Dealer," was appointed director of the National Youth Administration
for the Northern Illinoi s District, and was named the group's state director in 1939; and
WHEREAS, Herbert Bain began his career in public relations when he moved from the HeraldAmerican to become infonnation director for the Chrysler Corporation' s Chicago Dodge plant, and later
moved to New York to take a job with Ivy Lee and T.J. Ross; and
WHEREAS, Herbert Bain continued to excel in the field of public relations, becoming public relations
director of the American Dental Association in Chicago in 1954, before moving to the American Meat
Institute, where he served as public relations director and then assistant to the President; and
WHEREAS, Mary Bain first met Sidney R. Yates in 1948 during his first run for Congress; and
WHEREAS, Mary Bain would work alongside Representative Yates for over 50 years, including 33
years as his Chief of Staff in Washington, D.C. and retired in 1998 as the last working member of the
Roosevelt Administration; and
WHEREAS, Herbert Bain was a leader in his profession, as a Fellow of the Public Relations Society of
America, and serving on its board of directors, and as president of its Chicago chapter; and
WHEREAS, Herbert Bain was recognized for his dedication to the community, evidenced by his cosponsoring of Dr. Martin Luther King's first speech to the Chicago business community, when he
received the Paul Lund Award for public service from the Public Relations Society and the David Apter
Award for community service from the National Capital Chapter; and
WHEREAS, Mary Bain worked tirelessly with Representative Yates on important matters, such as
preservation of arts funding, the establishment of the U.S. Holocaust Memorial Museum in Washington,
programs that are credited with saving thousands of old books and artifacts, the Brittle Books and
National Heritage Preservation programs, the latter of which honored Mary Bain as a Heritage Defender;
and
WHEREAS, Herbert and Mary Bain are survived by their daughter, Mary Ellen Bain and two grandsons;
and
WHEREAS, Herbert and Mary Bain will be deeply missed and forever treasured by all who knew them
and the people of Cook County owe a debt of gratitude to Herbert and Mary Bain for their extensive
community service and outstanding civic involvement.
NOW, THEREFORE, BE IT RESOLVED, that the Board of Commissioners of Cook County does
hereby offer its deepest condolences and most heartfelt sympathy to the family and friends of Herbert and
Mary Bain and joins them in sorrow at this time of Joss; and
BE IT FURTHER RESOLVED, that a suitable copy of this Resolution be spread upon the official
proceedings of this Honorable Body and that an official copy of same be tendered to the family of Herbert
and Mary Bain so that their memory may be so honored and ever cherished.

401

 JOURNAL OF PROCEEDINGS FOR SEPTEMBER 7, 2006

Approved and adopted this 7th day of September 2006.
BOBBIE L. STEELE, President
Cook County Board of Commissioners
Attest: DAYID ORR, County Clerk

adopted. The motion carried unanimously.

IN MEMORY OF PATRICK WILLIAM O'BRIEN
WHEREAS, Patrick O' Brien died on August 11, 2006 in his home in Evanston; and
WHEREAS, Patrick O'Brien spent more than 50 years as a trial lawyer and was a leader in the practice
oflaw, being listed in the Best Lawyers in America for many years; and
HEREAS, Patrick O' Brien was a mentor to young attorneys and generous in sharing his experiences;
and
1
\\

WHEREAS, Patrick O'Brien was born in 1927 and attended St. Athanasius School and Evanston
Township High School in Evanston before receiving a bachelor's degree in mechanical engineering from
Northwestern University in 1947; and
WHEREAS, Patrick O'Brien contemplated a career in academia but chose law after encouragement from
a professor; and
WHEREAS, in 1950, Patrick O'Brien earned a degree in law from Northwestern University, where he
was a member of the Order of the Coif and served as the associate editor of the Law Review; and

402

 JOURNAL OF PROCEEDINGS FOR SEPTEMBER 7, 2006

WHEREAS, Patrick O ' Brien joined the Air Force during the Korean War, becoming a captain and
working in the department of the judge advocate general; and

WHEREAS, in 1953, Patrick O'Brien returned to Chicago and joined Mayer, Meyer, Austrian & Platt;
and

WHEREAS, Patrick O ' Brien met his wife, Deborah Bissell in 1954 and the two were married in 1955;
and

WHEREAS, Patrick O'Brien used his battles with alcoholism to mentor young colleagues and wrote an
article about his experiences for the Chicago Bar Association; and

WHEREAS, Patrick O ' Brien served as president of the state Lawyers' Assistance Program, which helps
lawyers deal with substance-abuse issues; and

WHEREAS, Patrick O'Brien is survived by his wife Deborah, his daughters Kathy Caplice, Mariellen
Hendricks and Patti Sheahan, his sons Patrick and Jim, and twelve grandchildren and was preceded in
death by his daughter Eileen and his son Michael, and brothers Jim and Paul; and

WHEREAS, Patrick O' Brien will be deeply missed and forever treasured by all who knew him and the
people of Cook County owe a debt of gratitude to Patrick O'Brien for his extensive community service
and outstanding civic involvement.

NOW, THEREFORE, BE IT RESOLVED, that the Board of Commissioners of Cook County does
hereby offer its deepest condolences and most heartfelt sympathy to the family and friends of Patrick
O'Brien and joins them in sorrow at this time of loss; and

BE IT FURTHER RESOLVED, that a suitable copy of this Resolution be spread upon the official
proceedings of this Honorable Body and that an official copy of same be tendered to the family of Patrick
O'Brien so that hi s memory may be so honored and ever cherished.

COUNTY COMMISSIONERS
HONORING CHIEF FRANK KAMINSKI
WHEREAS, Frank Kaminski retired as Chief of Police of the Evanston Police Department on August I,
2006 after 32 years of service to the Evanston community; and
WHEREAS, Frank Kaminski has faithfully and capably served the residents of the City of Evanston and
worked tirelessly to promote a positive bond between the community and his department; and
WHEREAS, Frank Kaminski utilized his background in financial management, labor relations,
community policing, 91 1 enhancement, media relations and criminal investigation to make the Evanston
Police Department an example among police departments; and
WHEREAS, Frank Kaminski was a leader in his field, serving as a founding member of the National
Association of Police Planners, becoming the organization's first vice president and later serving as
president, and spearheading the fonnation of the Illinois Association of Police Planners; and
WHEREAS, Frank Kaminski has supported innovative new programs and procedures with the aim of
improving policing, such as the Commission for Accreditation of Law Enforcement Agencies (CALEA),
where he is a member of the evaluation team, and making the Evanston Police Department available to be
a jurisdiction for a sequential lineup identification procedure pilot program; and
WHEREAS, Frank Kaminski has made mentoring future generations of law enforcement professionals a
priority throughout his career, teaching regularly at facilities such as Northwestern University's Traffic
Institute and NEMRT (North East Multi-Regional Training, Inc.) and implementing programs for the
mentoring of middle managers by top officials at the Evanston Police Department; and
WHEREAS, Frank Kaminski received his bachelor's degree in criminal justice from the University of
Illinois and his masters in public administration from Roosevelt University and attended the FBI National
Academy, the Senior Management Institute at Harvard University, FBI Law Enforcement Executive
Development Seminar (LEEDS), and Northwestern 's Kellogg School of Management's Executive
Institute; and

404

 JOURNAL OF PROCEEDINGS FOR SEPTEMBER 7, 2006

WHEREAS, upon his retirement from the Evanston Police Department, Cook County owes a debt of
gratitude to Chief Frank Kaminski for his inspiring and successful public service and leadership.
NOW, THEREFORE, BE IT RESOLVED, that the Board of Commissioner of Cook County does
hereby congratulate Chief Frank Kaminski on his retirement from the Evanston Police Department and
wishes him happiness, good health, and success in his impressive future endeavor; and
BE IT FURTHER RESOLVED, that a suitable copy of this Resolution be tendered to Chief Frank
Kaminski as a symbol of this auspicious occasion and let it also be spread upon the official proceedings of
this Honorable Body.
Approved and adopted this 7th day of September 2006.
BOBBIE L. STEELE, President
Cook County Board of Commissioners
Attest: DAVID ORR, County Clerk

adopted. The motion carried unanimously.
