COUNTY COMMISSIONERS
IN MEMORY OF LAWREN CE GENE LAVEN GOOD
WHEREAS, Lawrence Gene Lavengood died on July 12, 2006 at the age of82; and
WHEREAS, Gene Lavengood was a retired professor at Northwestern University's J.L. Kellogg
Graduate School of Management, as well as a tireless participant and leader in the civic life of Evanston;
and

405

 JOURNAL OF PROCEEDINGS FOR SEPTEMBER 7, 2006

WHEREAS, Gene Lavengood was born on June 30, 1924 in Tulsa, Oklahoma, enrolled in Tulane
University in New Orleans, and transferred to the University of Chicago, where he received his bachelor's
degree, a master' s degree in 1947 and a doctorate in U.S. history in 1953; and
WHEREAS, Gene Lavengood met his wife Gloria at the University of Chicago and enjoyed 44 years of
marriage until Mrs. Lavengood's death in 1991; and
WHEREAS, during his studies at the University of Chicago Gene Lavengood began to develop his
sensitivity to social involvement that would guide much of his life; and
WHEREAS, Gene Lavengood acted on this sensibility when, in 1961, he was a part of a group of
families that formed the Dewey Community Conference, an organization that worked to stabilize the
neighborhood during the period of school integration; and
WHEREAS, Gene Lavengood promoted the concept of school integration during his tenure on the
Evanston-Skokie School District 65 Board of Education; and
WHEREAS, Gene Lavengood began his life in Evanston and his tenure at Northwestern University as a
teacher in 1953 and retired from Kellogg in 1994; and
WHEREAS, as a testament to his effect on students and the school as a whole, Kellogg named its highest
teaching award after Gene Laven good, the Lavengood Outstanding Professor of the Year Award; and
WHEREAS, Gene Lavengood continued his work to further race relations in Evanston and at
Northwestern through his involvement in the Leadership Education and Development initiative at
Kellogg, an outreach program that encourages minority high school students to pursue business careers;
and
WHEREAS, Gene Lavengood is survived by his daughters Jessica Lettow, Abigail Dumas and Rachel
Lavengood, his son Timothy Lavengood, two sisters, Betsy Wilson and Katie Johnson, four grandchildren
and one great-grandchild; and
WHEREAS, Gene Lavengood will be deeply missed and forever treasured by all who knew him and the
people of Cook County owe a debt of gratitude to Gene Lavengood for his extensive community service
and outstanding civic involvement.
NOW, THEREFORE, BE IT RESOLVED, that the Board of Commissioners of Cook County does
hereby offer its deepest condolences and most heartfelt sympathy to the family and friends of Gene
Lavengood and joins them in sorrow at this time of loss; and
BE IT FURTHER RESOLVED, that a suitable copy of this Resolution be spread upon the official
proceedings of this Honorable Body and that an official copy of same be tendered to the family of Gene
Lavengood so that his memory may be so honored and ever cherished.
Approved and adopted this 7th day of September 2006.
BOBBIE L. STEELE, President
Cook County Board of Commissioners
Attest: DAVID ORR, County Clerk

for the last three years has served as Executive Sales and Marketing for the Glenview Journal; and
WHEREAS, Lloyd Kuehn has been an active member of the Glenview Chamber of Commerce for
almost 20 years where he has served as a member of the Chambers Ambassador, Golf and Holiday Ball
Committees; and

board member and Vice President of Youth Services Glenview/Northbrook and began the Holiday Gift
Program and the Youth Services Police Person of the Year Award; and
WHEREAS, in addition Lloyd Kuehn chaired the nominating committee of the Glenview Historical
Society, served as board member of Helping Hands of Glenview and chaired the Junior Golf Community
Outreach Committee bringing the first golf programs to the children of Maryville Academy and
established the Eli Cotes Sportsmanship Award at Glenbrook South High School; and
WHEREAS, Lloyd Kuehn's extensive community service also includes serving as President of the
Optimist club; and
WHEREAS, Lloyd Kuehn served our country in the U.S. Marine Corp as a member of the Marine Air
Wing, serving at the Glenview Naval Air Station as one of his duty stations and continued to stay active
in the military as a charter member of the Hanger One Foundation, board member of the Navy League
Glenview Council and Post 166 of the American Legion; and

407

Chamber of Commerce's " Business Person of the Year" and commend him for his countless hours of
service to the community; and
BE IT FURTHER RESOLVED, that a copy of this Resolution be tendered to Lloyd Kuehn m
commemoration of this auspicious occasion.

06-R-350
RESOLUTION
Sponsored by
THE HONORABLE JERRY BUTLER, COUNTY COMMISSIONER
Co-Sponsored by
THE HONORABLE BOBBIE L. STEELE, PRESIDENT, FORREST CLAYPOOL,

MIKE QUIGLEY, PETER N. SILVESTRI, DEBORAH SIMS AND LARRY SUFFREDIN
COUNTY COMMISSIONERS
WHEREAS, Almighty God in His Infinite wisdom, called James L. Mack from our midst, on August 6,
2006; and
WHEREAS, James Mack distinguished himself in all areas of music, as a conductor, composer, arranger,
singer and instrumentalist. He was a luminous and munificent talent who inspired many musicians; and
WHEREAS, James Mack received his B.M (1952) and M.M. (1954) from Roosevelt University, he was
also a Ford Foundation Fellow and Fellow of the Contemporary Chamber Players at the University of
Chicago. He joined the City Colleges of Chicago in 1956 and was Chainnan of the Music and
Humanities department for over 30 years retiring in 1998 as a Distinguished Professor; and

409

 JOURNAL OF PROCEEDINGS FOR SEPTEMBER 7, 2006

WHEREAS, James Mack had a long and distinguished musical career, he conducted his works with the
Chicago Symphony Orchestra at Symphony Center and Ravinia, the Grant Park Orchestra and orchestras
in Atlanta, Dallas, Cincinnati, Houston, Los Angeles, Indianapolis, Kansas City, Oregon, Toledo,
Vancouver, the Washington National Orchestra, and the London Philharmonic; and
WHEREAS, James Mack was a classically educated musician comfortable across the continuum of
music genres with over 60 albums to his credit for artist such as the Manhattans, Champaign, Tyrone
Davis, Nancy Wilson, Ramsey Lewis, Jerry Butler, Curtis Mayfield, Kokomo, Linda Clifford and the
labels of CBS, Capitol, Brunswick, Columbia Masterworks and Sony Classical. He was a Grammy
Award winner appearing in many radio and television commercials and host of a weekly jazz series; and
WHEREAS, James Mack received worldwide notoriety during his life and he remained entrenched in his
community serving as Minister of Music at the First Presbyterian Church of Chicago since 1974.
NOW, THEREFORE, BE IT RESOLVED, that the Cook County Board of Commissioners does
hereby extend their deepest condolences to the family of James L. Mack for their loss; and
BE IT FURTHER RESOLVED, that a suitable copy of this Resolution be tendered to the family of
James L. Mack in his honor and be spread upon the official proceedings of this Honorable Body.
Approved and adopted this 7th day of September 2006.

Cook County Board of Commissioners
Attest: DAYID ORR, County Clerk

RESOLUTION

THE HONORABLE BOBBIE L. STEELE
PRESIDENT OF THE BOARD OF COMMISSIONE RS
CELEBRATION OF LIFE
MRS. VERNICE (TAYLOR) BROWNLEE
Proverbs 31
Who can find a virtuous woman, for her price is far above rubies? The heart of her husband doth
safely trust in her... She riseth also while it is yet night and feedeth her household.. She stretched
out her hand to the poor: yea, she reaches forth her hand to the needy. Many women do noble
things but you surpass them all.

410

 JOURNAL OF PROCEEDINGS FOR SEPTEMBER 7, 2006

WHEREAS, Almighty God in His Infinite wisdom called from our midst Vernice (Taylor) Brownlee
affectionately known as " Lady Brownlee"; and

WHEREAS, Vernice Brownlee was deeply involved with the senior citizens and the community of North
Lawndale. Each year she coordinated and sponsored a trip to Hot Springs, Arkansas where they could
bask in the sun and rejuvenate their body with water in Little Rock, Arkansas; and

WHEREAS, during these trips to Arkansas Vernice would treat them to one night delight where the
passengers were able to enjoy the Passion Play; and

WHEREAS, Vernice served as the Chainnan of the Better Boys Foundation and earned thousands of
dollars to help college bound students further their education; and

WHEREAS, during her tenure with the Department of Human Services each year Vernice worked many
block clubs in the community; and

WHEREAS, Vernice joined the Independence Blvd Seventh-Day Adventist Church in Chicago, Illinois.
Until her demise where she served as a Board Member, a Home and School Leader, and lngathering
Director just to name a few; and

WHEREAS, Vernice (Taylor) Brown lee' s (Lady Brownlee) legacy of Jove will live on in the memory of
her children and the lives that she touched.

NOW, THEREFORE, BE IT RESOLVED, that the Board of Commissioners of Cook County does
hereby offer its deepest condolences and most heartfelt sympathy to the family and friends of Vernice
(Taylor) Brownlee (Lady Brownlee) and joins them in sorrow at this time of loss; and

BE IT FURTHER RESOLVED, that a suitable copy of this Resolution be spread upon the official
proceedings of this Honorable Body and that an official copy of same be tendered to the family of
Vernice (Taylor) Brownlee so her memory may be honored and cherished.

411

 JOURNAL OF PROCEEDINGS FOR SEPTEMBER 7, 2006

* * * * *
06-R-352
RESOLUTION

Sponsored by
THE HONORABLE JOSEPH MARIO MORENO, COUNTY COMMISSIONER
Co-Sponsored by
THE HONORABLE ANTHONY J . PERAICA, DEBORAH SIMS,
ELIZABETH ANN DOODY GORMAN, JOAN PATRICIA MURPHY
AND PETER N. SILVESTRI, COUNTY COMMISSIONERS
WHEREAS, as mandated by state law, Cook County government has principal responsibility for the
protection of persons and property, the provision for public health services and the maintenance of
County highways; and
WHEREAS, inherent to this core mission, the County provides judicial and law enforcement services
comprising the Circuit Court of Cook County, which is the largest unified court system in the world; the
Cook County Department of Corrections, which is the largest single-site jail in the nation and the Cook
County Juvenile Temporary Detention Center, the first juvenile center in the nation and one of the largest;
the Bureau of Health Services, which administers the County's public health services and is the second
largest public health system in the nation; and the Cook County Highway Department which is
responsible for the design and maintenance of over 578 miles of roadways in the County; and
WHEREAS, public safety and healthcare services represent approximately 65% of Cook County's
Budget; and
WHEREAS, providing services related to our core mission is an increasingly expensive and difficult
undertaking, especially in light of ever escalating healthcare costs along with federal cuts in Medicaid and
Medicare; and
WHEREAS, obligating counties that spend more than $100 million a year on purchases for goods and
services to withhold 3% of almost every payment to a vendor or contractor on behalf of the federal
government, while not similarly obligating the private sector, puts counties such as Cook at a
disadvantage by increasing costs to finance government contracts; and
WHEREAS, the ability to competitively bid for contracts is a major component in helping keep costs
down; and
WHEREAS, although this unfunded mandate is not scheduled to become active until FY2011, the
expensive preparation and administrative changes necessary to implement it will need to take place prior
to its start date; and
WHEREAS, Cook County is already facing a budget crisis, with an approximately $56 million shortfall
for the current FY2006 budget and the FY2007 budget process fast approaching; and

412

 JOURNAL OF PROCEEDINGS FOR SEPTEMBER 7, 2006

WHEREAS, the departments that make up the government of Cook County are or may need to eliminate
important services, upon which our citizens have come to rely in order to present balanced budgets in the
future; and
WHEREAS, federal and/or state unfunded mandates only serve to compound the problem of trying to
pay for services integral to our core mission by reallocating monies to pay for these mandates, which
would otherwise be used to provide County services; and
WHEREAS, the manner in which this unfunded mandate was passed, lacking the proper scrutiny, is
antithetical to the Unfunded Mandates Reform Act.
NOW, THEREFORE, BE IT RESOLVED, that the Cook County Board of Commissioners, does
hereby urge the United States Congress to repeal this major unfunded mandate, so as not to further burden
counties such as Cook with costly programs, which only serve to complicate the task of providing core
services to our citizens without increasing revenues via such unpopular measures as raising taxes and
fees ; and
BE IT FURTHER RESOLV ED, that a suitable copy of this Resolution be delivered to the U.S.
Congressmen representing the congressional districts within Cook County, as well as Senators Barack
Obama and Richard Durbin.
Approved and adopted this 7th day of September 2006.
BOBBIE L. STEELE, President
Cook County Board of Commissioners
Attest: DA YID ORR, County Clerk

Commissioner Moreno, seconded by Commissioner Silvestri, moved to suspend the rules so that this
matter may be considered. The motion carried unanimously.
Commissioner Moreno, seconded by Commissioner Silvestri , moved that the Resolution be approved and
adopted. The motion carried unanimously.

Board of Commissioners. Mr. Blakemore spoke concerning several issues regard ing Cook County.

and Members of the Cook County Board of Commissioners. Mr. Hunter spoke regarding union issues.

 JOURNAL OF PROCEEDINGS FOR SEPTEMBER 7, 2006
